Let me preface this review by saying that at this point in time, this game is loads of fun. There is still an issue with content variety compared to previous Battlefield titles, but comparing the current state of the game to the state at launch, it needs to be said that Battlefield 2042 has undergone massive improvements and changes, and it is an absolute blast to play. It feels like a classic online shooter experience, with no stat-tracking BS skill based matchmaking systems forcing you into a 50/50 win-loss ratio and throwing you into games that feel completely unfair and rigged. Lobbies feel like organic random selections of players matched together based on their connection instead of their stats, and all of this deserves to be praised. It truly is a great time. 

 That is, when it works.

 There are still issues with the game, balancing issues, baked in flaws with certain mechanics that were ill conceived and cannot be fixed without a complete overhaul of the game. There are issues with the core design philosophy of the operator system, which even with the addition of conventional classes still muddies the identity of Battlefield. There are occasional minor bugs and glitches, none of which are game breaking and can usually be fixed with a restart of the game. But the absolute biggest issue with BF2042, is the EA app, and EA's DREADFUL online service. 

 There is a major bug within the EA service itself that makes friends appear offline, even when they're not. Even when you're all in game trying to invite each other, you simply can't because they do not appear in the social tab. There is no fix for this. There is seemingly no reason for this, and no cause. No amount of restarting the game or EA app will fix this. It simply decides when it does or doesn't want to allow you to play with friends. 

 Friends will appear online in the EA app, though it will not show that they are in game, even though THEY ARE. You cannot view them in the social tab in-game, and therefore cannot invite them, because the EA app lacks BASIC SOCIAL FEATURES, such as SENDING GAME INVITES!!!! 

 The only choices you have are; 
 1: Pray. 
 2: find something else to do for the rest of the day, because there is nothing you can do to fix this issue. It's not on your end. Unlucky.

 No amount of restarts, verifying game files or repairing damaged files, system restarts, or uninstalling will fix this issue. It will simply work again for no reason in a few hours, or within a day or so. Trying to play with friends in this game is a ****ING NIGHTMARE and randomly cripples your ability to party up, which is such a shame because when it works, it's so much fun. 

 2042 has had a rough time getting to a playable state. The launch was one of the worst in video game history. And even though it's in a much better state now, EA's incompetence is still holding it back from reaching it's full potential. I cannot recommend this game with the experience I've had, not based on the game itself, but based solely on the bare-bones, incompetent, poorly designed, poorly maintained, and entirely dysfunctional EA app that players are forced to use. EA, fix your broken systems and services, or get rid of them completely and let us play our games through Steam.

This game has come a long way from its disastrous launch. I've had a lot of fun with my friends on it. They started finally delivering content on the Gold pass. I don't feel like I got completely scammed any more. Most of the technical issues have been fixed, and DICE is still adding new content. It's fun, and its a Battlefield title through and through. That being said, the price point is steep for what you get. I recommend the game to Battlefield lovers, however I strongly recommend waiting for it to go on sale or finding a 3rd-party seller (see: isthereanydeal).

Bad game. Dont be fooled like i was with the cool cinematics. Its impossible to run over 30 fps constantly even with a good pc, the gun play is stale, the movement is clunky, and dosnt feel like a battlefield game what so ever. The operators are bland and uninteresting, and the cars, tanks, and planes are just as clunky as the rest of the game.

Disregard the negative reviews - for real. I think some of the reviewers are jumping on a boat with the negativity.

Gameplay? It's actually decent. Well balanced, not great but well balanced. Gunsfeel fun and you dont need to put a lot of bullets into enemy for them to stop - so more reality.

Graphics? Jeez. Some of the darker maps brings memories from BF3. Love it. 

Specialists. I thought they were going to be like in apex - but not at all. They are great. Not too op gadgets (except scout drone) but all-around fun specialists. I've got few favourites.

Not too many hackers - so far in 24 in-game hours.

I can admit that this game is a more of a COD game than BF game. Would love to have more slower gagmeplay, especially in narrow conquest games.

After many hours and multiple seasons of playing this game I will recommend you buy this under a few conditions.

-If the game is heavily discounted.

-If you are willing to spend money on a game that will possibly lose support the moment a breath of the 'next Battlefield game is coming out' (it’s what happened to Battlefield V and Battlefront II 2017 when this was announced loosely) 

-Finally, knowing full well that this game is not being made by the same DICE team that has made many of the games in the past that just play better in many ways. 

I hate to say that I don’t think this is what Battlefield is anymore, I will say it isn’t as horrible as it was at launch but there are so many weird things going on, for example, the game feels like nothing has weight, when you turn left and right or look up and down the game just feels as if everything is made of paper and cardboard, another example is that almost all of the weapons in this game are just laser beams from any range, why?. 

Just know that with whatever the next Battlefield title will be, the launch of this game and this game alone is what that game [b] CAN NOT BE. [/b]
I love Battlefield, and I really don’t mind what 2042 has become. But please do not expect much from this very hollow game.

When the game first came out i was appalled at the state of it.  Tried to refund the 100ish dollars i spent on it but steam wouldnt give the refund because i spent more than an hour in the game.  BUT now that they have fixed 90 percent of the major issues i am quite happy.  It finally feels like it shouldve from the beginning.  It is a shame that most of the players are gone now.  

Game play feels fluid, guns feel good, attachments seem to make a difference even if its minimal.  Only huge complaint i have is the engineer AT/Javelin/RPG  feel useless takes wayyyyy too many rockets to kill any armor.  The fact that the choppers and planes do not have to go back to a landing strip or helipad to get more flares or repair or reload guns like it used to be in earlier battlefields makes killing planes and choppers VERY VERY VERY hard.  Not a fan of it.  On most maps its pointless getting in armor because of the air support.  

Another small complaint there is no limit of the amount of any one class on a map.  So everyone plays sniper or engineers and you end up with 40 snipers on a team or 40 engineers and you either get scoped nonstop the second you spawn or if youre in armor yet again 20 javelins tossed at you less than 2 minutes into spawning a tank you waited for 4 minutes for. 

Other than those few things I am fairly happen with the game.  I just hope the next battlefield they learn their damn lesson and do not release a shit game that takes 2 years to fix to get to the playable point.

I spent £100 on this and in return received an unoptimised, unfinished game. The game doesn’t even have a scoreboard or any detailed statistics page to show my k/d ratio and accomplishments. Not to mention the fact that I run the game with everything on low settings with DLSS and only achieve 120fps. Can’t even reach my monitors 144hz refresh rate which is a complete joke when it’s 2022 and games like PUBG with bigger maps can achieve a stable 200fps.

I finally decided to come back to this game after 2 years and it's finally an enjoyable and playable experience. In its original state I would have never in a million years recommended this game to anyone, but now it's actually a decent game. The only downside that I have noticed so far is the lag of animations across multiple maps such as the rocket world event on Orbital due to the 20hz tick rate servers on solo/co-op. When the rocket is flying up into the air, it doesn't look smooth at all; like going up and down whilst travelling up as if it was lagging despite me being on 25-30ms latency. This isn't an issue on the normal online servers as they're 45hz tick rate. Other than that, I would recommend this game now in its current state for anyone who is a Battlefield fan.

Recently bought it here on steam to achievement hunt, after having 600-ish hours over on EA. Let's just cut to the chase. Is it as good as BF3, 4 or 1? No. The "premium" edition priced over 100$€ at launch was an embarrassing money grab for no substantial content at all. The lack of a proper server browser hinders the game so much. It basically makes the game unplayable outside peak hours as everyone just gets spread out over bot lobbies. How you've failed to implement this in like 2,5 years is beyond me. Where community ran servers were the exact thing that made BF 3,4 and 1 so good and is keeping them alive to this day.

But looking past the way EA fumbled the ball with this game. By showing no comprehension at all of knowing what their community loved about the franchise. A sad thing more developers suffer from these days. Overall, looking past all its flaws, I really enjoy playing the game. And would certainly recommend it on sale.

It's just a shame it could and should just be so much better if they had paid any kind of attention to their community.

This is all from 12 mins of actual gameplay. The rest of my time was literally fixing problems, cut scenes, and some modding in the lobby before realizing as a level one I had nothing.

This isn't a battlefield game. I'm forced to download 3rd party software (EA's Launcher) which also starts up alongside my normal routines which adds another thing to roll my eyes at when I boot up. The game play is literally just CoD with the ADHD kids and rhetoric in chat logs. After buying the game, there are the unstoppable first play cut scene (I had to stop the game wholesale via task manager just to avoid it which resulted in another unskippable cut scene) alongside a conquest mode tutorial and game which I find predatory since they're intentionally doing that to prevent people from refunding since it adds play time without actual play. Before even playing a match, I had to fix and optimize my settings in game since it somehow confused my monitor with a 144hz as opposed to 60 which to be fair might've just been an odd bug since once I made the switch.

All of this to say that was a ton of effort to just get into the game. The wait time for me was 2ish minutes on a weekday, so I'm sure on the weekend its bumping so no complaints there. The menu loading times on the other hand. Sure 2-3 seconds, I'm used to BF taking not even a second with scaled down UI as opposed to feeling like I'm in a e-store the entire time.

TLDR: Its not old BF (BC2, BF3, or BF4) its a great rendition of CoD tho with BF game modes so if that's your what you're looking for definitely buy it! If you grew up (2008-2014) causing war crimes like me on BF this isn't the game for you. For those that feel the need to leap to its defense, its not a bad game. Its just not what was advertised to me (imo), and its difficult to point out clear differences since I've been away for over a decade. Its just not the old BF fun. Now its more fun for the competitiveness(?) idk how to describe it. It just feels like this wasn't made by the same company as Bad Company 2

My initial review was written at 110 hours of playtime. After some progress, I am reassessing the game at over 250 hours, and level 100 (S001) ranking in the game. 2042 has historically been a game of contestation, so I'll be highlighting over the biggest aspects.

Overall, I *recommend* Battlefield 2042 for people who want an FPS emblematic of PUBG and older game titles.

[h3]Specialists, styles & game play tactics[/h3]

In 2042, you are given a total of 14 operators, officially called "specialists." Much like Rainbow Six Siege, each specialist tailors to focusing on a specific playing style per class. As a new player, you will most likely play one or more of the following:

- MacKay (Assault)
- Boris (Engineer)
- Falck (Support)
- Casper (Recon)

There is no variance in the fundamentals of a class, regardless of whoever you choose. You should find a specialist that fits best with your playing style so you can become more in-tune with the game. For assault players, your main focus is in infantry aggression, pushing into objectives and acting as a first-line. Engineers cater vehicular activities, found in Rush, Conquest, and Breakthrough. (Rush + Conquest) Support and recon are as self-explanatory as the assault class.

Whether you're playing Team Deathmatch, Rush or any other game mode, there are "meta" tactics used by most common regular players, such as "dropshot"-ing and spawncamping. 2042 is reminiscent of COD, be wary when starting.

[h3]Gun play & levelling[/h3]

**Gun play in 2042 is broken**. To learn more, consider watching [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3sd9QooFI9k]this YouTube video[/url].

Weapons are categorically divided into five: SMG, Assault, (e.g. carbine-based) LMG, DMR, (e.g. marksman/rifle-based weapons) Sniper, and Tactical. Approximately half of all SMG and Assault weapons will come with little-to-no recoil. All other categories will have marginally wide bullet spread and adverse vertical recoil; and attachments are required to be unlocked via. kills or prerequisite challenges.

These are the best weapons to start with (as a beginner) if you wish to have a balanced experience between levelling and playing:

- M5A3
- VHX-D3
- AM40
- K30
- PBX-45
- DM7
- SWS-10
- MCS-880

[h3]Multiplayer & network connections[/h3]

2042 has a slight problem with keeping persistent connections between clients and servers. You should expect occasional and common disconnects. This may or may not be a dealbreaker for some, as of Season 6, persistence loss has significantly decreased.

(EDIT AT 102.4 HOURS PLAYED: EA app has stopped working for me and the game is now unplayable. Save your money)

The game has come a very long way since it launched way back when, and has massively improved. 

I recently got this and have been playing it like crack, guns feel good, the devs are actually trying to go back to what made Battlefield Battlefield (although it's hard due to the foundation that this game laid down initially).

Maps range from good to alright, none are offensively bad, the scale is enormous and it still manages to look great despite its size.

All in all, worth a purchase! Though maybe wait for a sale, it's not worth full price (though no multiplayer game ever is)

Yes this game was released without the most common multiplayer gameplay features like voice chat, and a leaderboard when you tab out. It was buggy and totally incomplete when released. I bought the game 8 months after the release date and it felt really good. It's been updated and feels so much better on mouse and keyboard as well. If they announced the game as early access back then it would've made sense but here we are. The game is really fun right now. Even though it was a MEME at release. I still think BFV has the best gunplay, 2042 is right behind it.

If you've played battlefield in the past, this does not feel like the same game whatsoever. It's sorta fun but I feel like I ran into bugs more than I had fun moments so far. I'd wait to buy this until like November of NEXT year because it's hard to imagine good changes are gonna come any time soon.

EDIT** It's okay. Still plays well, but alot of problems to be fixed. I'm having fun and am excited to see dice putting the effort in with these updates.

EDIT*** It's not okay. Buy this if its like 20 bucks and don't go into this expecting battlefield.

EDIT**** Game is actually at a good place finally (2/18/2024) and is nice casual fun. Pick it up if it's under 10 and it's a pretty good bang for your buck.

There's probably better shooters out there but I still can find fun in BF2042. I wouldnt buy it at full price or recommend anyone to do so.  There's a ton of pay for convenience, which I always find dumb but at least there's no pay to win guns (that I know of as a filthy casual). Battlefield will always be great if you're lookng for more than a shooter, you get rewarded for being full on support, spotting enemies or resuppling ammo, etc. It really does feel like a war, especially the 128v128 mode(sadly, a ton of not so bright AI fill both teams...expected or que times would be long.) 

Pick up on sale and enjoy it for a war simulator and remember this game has a mixed review score for a reason..Some people enjoy it, some don't. Be sure to make your mind up before going over the 2hr limit for refund.

Pre-ordered this game and was super excited as I love Battlefield. 
Upon installing the game I was GREATLY disappointed. I spent the first 2 hours trying to find a stable match that didnt disconnect me and spit errors at me which I was unfamiliar with. 

Steam and EA were less than helpful with their support leaving me frustrated to the point of uninstalling. 

I waited a few updated and give it a try again, to be yet again disappointed, this Battlefield feels like its trying to be COD. It has lost what made Battlefield its own game and for that I uninstalled it a second time and haven't toughed it since. 

I was able to play maybe a total of 8 hours as the rest was trying to figure out what was wrong with the game and getting disconnected. Im sure this problem has been since resolved.

Bought BF2042 for $10 USD and that's exactly what it's worth. After playing a couple of hours, I really enjoy the experience of getting back into a modern Battlefield game. The guns feel really satisfying to use, the 128 player conquest games are very intense. However, what I will say is that the graphics don't look as good as BF5 or even BF1. I was disappointed when I loaded into the different maps and didn't see the normal DICE/Battlefield insane graphics.

While still switching back to BF5 and BF1 often, it is nice to have a new shooter to play during a time when good new shooter games are rare. I'd recommend it, but only on a deeply discounted sale.

Battlefield 2042 offers an experience that, on the surface, seems to fulfill the franchise's promises, yet it falls short of capturing the essence that fans have come to love. The game is marred by a repetitive gameplay loop that, despite its scale, fails to leverage this advantage effectively. Historically, the series has been celebrated for its emergent gameplay, where the vast, highly detailed maps and the dynamic ability to alter the battlefield play a central role. Unfortunately, these elements feel notably absent or underutilized in Battlefield 2042, leading to a sense of disconnection and disappointment when compared to its predecessors.

Additionally, the introduction of more unrealistic features has diluted the sense of immersion that is crucial to the Battlefield experience. This shift away from what made the series stand out has been a significant detractor for me. Given these factors, I find it difficult to recommend Battlefield 2042. It seems as though the developers have lost sight of the core attributes that previously defined and elevated the franchise.

I have been recently playing BFV because it was the most realistic and fun of the modern Battlefields, waited 2 years to finally try this one due to the bad reviews and i have got to say i dont mind them, i respect opinions, and i m glad i bought it right now, been a hell of a ride, so much fun i m having right now! Modern Warfare, Russians, Americans, well yea i would not mind taking those drones away but all in all, superb game, i never played these games for story anyways, it is all about the chaos in multiplayer and the destruction, so far... loving the new classes and being able to choose a character with dif perks.
Reminds me a lot of Battlefield 4, and most of the maps are very dynamic and interesting, loving it.

Cons:
- Long loading screens even with an SSD M2NVme 4.0
- Every time i log in i have to be reminded of your Battlepass, i dont give a DAM* About your Battlepass, i dont need it, Battlefield dont need it.
- Way many information on the Menu and i would rather have a cleaner HUD when playing.
- Even though i do like that now characters have so much more gadgets, i would like a more realistic approach rather than stupid wingsuits and grappling hooks.
- Team Death Match maps are not made for team death match, none of them are, they just cut conquest maps in half and tag it has TDM, it is not a classic TDM experience like they call it, you dont have a base where you spawn, it keeps changing spawns so it makes it frustrating to play because many times you spawn around enemies;
- Same goes for classic modes like conquest, spawns are very mediocre and sometimes you spawn miles away from the objective, even sometimes 2 meters from an enemy.
- Modes like breakthrough should not have vehicles, as some people block entry points to sites and it is nearly impossible for defending teams to have a chance to win.

Few cheaters here and there, other than that, Incredible audio as usual and amazing visuals.
8.5/10

Yeah, love the addition of specialist moves - adds depth to strategy, especially as an engineer focused on eliminating armor. I love the sentry turret and ability to call in a security dog. Makes for the perfect cover as you sit behind / near enemy lines, destroying armor from a safe distance, acting as a droppoint for your squad to move closer to the target. For my computer, which is a $1000 budget micro PC, I run on low graphics and can handle 128 player servers with a low tick below 50, but the frame rate averages about 40 and drops to mid 20's to low 30's in heavy combat situations. However, it's still playable if I am careful and find great firing positions rather than constantly run and gun - as my objective is to destroy enemy armor. The jets are a great addition, and mouse flying 5th gen is incredibly smooth. Vehicle driving is greatest it's been, and up there with the dedicated greats like need for speed. I really like racing ground vehicles, and driving tanks feels very, very smooth. I put hours into BF4 over the years, and although my mini PC isn't the fastest, I am glad I can play relatively smooth and excited for the future of BattleField franchise. If it's playable, similiar to high on BF4 then it's an excellent edition to anyones library, especially on sale.

Update Update: There were a few things I got wrong. The content is not blocked behind a paywall, rather the elite edition allows you to unlock several weapons and vehicles early. The elite edition is pointless because you can simply play solo in an AI match, farm the bots to meet the unlock requirements, and unlock all the weapons and vehicles in a few hours. If you look into it, the game had a rough development because corporate was trying to ride the hype train and make a CoD Warzone wannabe, complete with lore that gets released on a season-by-season basis that no one cares about, and unique soldiers with specific abilities that are either totally useless or completely overpowered. The game is fine for some mindless fun if you get it discounted. But honestly it sucks because it suffers from the same issues that plague every single battlefield game, but are amplified by a hundred because of these unique characters that don't belong in this IP.

For example, tanks or heavy vehicles would rather camp at spawn because if they get too close to the combat zone, Mackay is going to use his grappling gun from half a football field away to get on top of the tank where no one can hit him, spread his cheeks and dump his load of C5 before twerking away into the sunset with his finger on the detonator. Same goes for wingsuit bitch doing the same thing but flying across the entire map instead. If you thought 2142 was ass because of suicide bombers, well you ain't seen shit.

Update: Oh yeah and EA Anti cheat just booted me from a match and shut down my game... while I was playing solo against the AI...

I just got it recently and despite the negativity that surrounded the game when it first came out, I can say that the game is fun and I haven't encountered any bugs so far. This is my first battlefield game that I've played since Bad Company 2 and Battlefield 3, and this game doesn't live up to them. The game play is fun and the shooting is satisfying, but that's about it. The maps are boring. They're too open, spaced out, and there's no real flow to them. The destructible environments might as well not exist. The classes are also boring. 

The game play feels watered down because it doesn't feel dynamic and it just comes down to shooting. Each class has a certain special ability like all the other battlefield games, but since the game play is so fast paced and the maps are so open, they don't feel unique or have any real utility. Medics can be useful sometimes, but if you have decent squad mates, then they can revive you anyway regardless of their class. Also since any class can use any type of weapon, it makes the class type even more moot. Sure each class specializes in a certain weapon type and they gain certain benefits from it, but it's really not that big of a hindrance to use a different weapon.

I can't really explain it, but between the poor map design, the game's fast paced focus (faster than what a good Battlefield game feels like), and the fading of classes, it just feels like a watered down shooter that looks like a Battlefield game, but lost touch with what a Battlefield game is suppose to be. All I want is more Bad Company.

Actually, all I want is a 2142 remake.

Also, fuck you EA for locking a third of your content behind the elite edition.

Is it worth $10.00? For some mindless fun, sure. It beats getting an aneurysm from sweating in Warzone. Is it ever worth handing over your money to EA? Absolutely the fuck not.

Battlefield no longer makes you think about the weapons you bring and class you play as.
Battlefield no longer feels like a military shooter. 
Battlefield no longer feels like Battlefield.

As a long-term Battlefield player, I've played every game for hundreds of hours each since Bad Company 2. I now have 100 hours on Steam, plus another 200 or so on PS5, so I've played quite a bit. I rarely write reviews, but I wanted to offer a perspective from someone who is a long-term player and is actually still playing.

I skipped the first 2 years of this game because of the awful launch. I tried the beta and was completely disappointed. I had faith that they would fix it eventually, as they always do, but this was the first time I actually didn't even want to play a Battlefield game at launch.

Fans of previous Battlefield games can have a lot of fun here now. Try the 64-player Conquest mode instead of 128. They didn't get the 128-player mode right, and it still feels a bit ridiculous if you're a long-term Battlefield player. Nobody likes feeling like what you and your squad do is essentially inconsequential, which is how the 128-player Conquest feels to me. The 128-player mode is a spectacle, but that's all it is to me. The 64-player mode fixes this: one player or squad can have a significant impact on the game, as it's always been with Battlefield.

The maps are plentiful and pretty solid overall. I get the feeling we won't be remembering how great any of these maps are in 5-10 years like we do with maps from BC2, BF3, and BF4, but there is a lot of fun to be had, and there is a good variety. Even though this game basically flopped, DICE & EA stuck with it. They improved it (as they do with every Battlefield game after a few years...) and kept adding content. Classes are back now (finally, DICE/EA, how did you think Operators were a good idea?), 64-player Conquest is in the game, and all the BC2 portal maps are in the main rotation.

There are still some issues: classes are back but not as they used to be, any class can use any primary weapon leading to a massive oversupply of Engineers, because why not if you can have the best AR in the game and RPGs at the same time. There are no consistent lobbies leading to playing the same map repeatedly, among some other things.

Performance is great, but I do have a 4070, so it's probably not a fair test reflective of what most people experience. However, it also did well on a 3060 I have in another computer, as it should. No random stutters or any of that nonsense. DLSS implementation here is great, I use quality mode at 1440P and see absolutely no downgrade in quality.

It still isn't quite the Battlefield game we deserved, but after some time and many fixes & changes, the game is in a good place & is well worth your time and the €11 asking price on sale.

Is BF2042 worth it in 2024? 

This game had a rough launch. I didnt play it for the whole first year it was out, even though I preordered it. 

But I can safely say that BF2042 is an excellent game (and has been for a few years). it is my default to return to when I am bored of everything else. 

People review bomb this game because they think they're taking a stance or something, but if you get it, you will enjoy yourself. It's Battlefield as always.

It's unfortunate really. I was having a pretty good time with the game and after a recent update, it has completely turned to crap.

The stuttering that has happened now makes the game unplayable,
I have to play the game in window mode or the picture is incredibly dim
Every time I spawn in the game completely locks up for 2 or 3 seconds (I do mean EVERY spawn)

The frustrating part of this is that I had no problems in August/September of last year. This all occurred around an update at the end of 2023. The game has become slightly better since then, but that's easy to do considering after the year-end update the game would 100% lock up and just repeat whatever last sound it heard until I completely closed the game out (The same 1-second gun-shot on repeat full blast in your ears is quite annoying), I guess we should count ourselves fortunate that was fixed.

If I could get a refund, I would. But the 30-plus hours I racked up before the game became unplayable will prevent that from happening. Maybe steer clear of this game, or don't. When it's playable it was fun, still BF3 and 4 were better titles.

TL;DR I would only recommend if you are REALLY bored and looking for something new to play. But even if you get to that point, I would recommend you just play Battlefield V instead. It has more players than 2042 everyday and is a better overall Battlefield experience.

I tried really hard to like this game, because I love Battlefield, and although there are some things it does well I can't recommend it to anyone looking for a genuine Battlefield experience. First and foremost, it has no single player experience. You may not think this is a big deal, but since almost every BF game before this have had single player campaigns that were genuinely well made, it feels scummy of them to not include one with this game and still ask for 60 dollars. 

Secondly, the hero/specialist system. At launch and for a couple seasons, there were only hero's in the game, each with their own special abilities, gadgets and passive perks instead of the traditional specialist system from previous BF games. This would have been an ok change, if they were balanced. Some felt significantly more powerful than others, and of course that led to EVERYONE using the same 2-3 heros, while the others were virtually unable to compete. However, they have since reintroduced the specialist system. So problem solved right? Absolutely not. Their way of adding a specialist system into this game was to take all heros, and divide them up into the 4 specialist categories. Additionally, each specialist class has a proficiency with a certain type of weapons (For example, Medic gets increased ADS speed with SMGs, Assault gets increased starting ammo with Assault Rifles, etc.) However, you are not locked to these weapon types per your specialist choice, meaning you can use whatever class of weapon you want with any specialist. Since the specialist weapon class proficiency perks are so bland and barely make a difference, most people still use whatever gun they want with whatever hero they want. The specialist system feels entirely pointless, and I can't help but feel DICE just shoehorned it in as a way to stop the players from complaining. 

Thirdly, gunplay and movement. Have you played any Call of Duty game since Modern Warfare 2019? If you answered yes, then you have already felt what 2042 gunplay and movement feels like. Although it doesn't feel bad by any means, I can't help but feel it's simply a lazy choice to simply copy modern CoD gameplay when Battlefield already had it's own identity in this regard. Guns have absolutely no recoil. Scope glint is now a thing, and since the movement is as fast as CoD movement now, you're shooting yourself in the foot for using a DMR or Sniper as Assault Rifles have egregiously good range and super fast ADS speed (and also no recoil as mentioned before) It features sprint and tactical sprint, but tac-sprint is INFINITE with no cooldown, and the ADS speed out of tac-sprint is the exact same speed as ADS speed out of normal sprint. Meaning tac-sprint is a total redundancy in the sandbox, and is only there as tool to say "Look CoD players, our game has tac-sprint and slide cancelling too!"

Fourth, the maps. The maps are where my only praise for this game comes in. The maps are gorgeous. Each features it's own theme reflected it it's name. Kaleidoscope is a futuristic city featuring a lot of polygonal architecture and clean, straight edges along with a great color palette.  Hourglass is a neon city of skyscrapers covered in sand dunes. Exposure features an underground lab cut in half and exposed by a massive landslide, featuring some really fun gameplay moments on top of, at the bottom of, and inside of a massive canyon wall. Like every other BF game, the maps have a great sense of scale and art direction. It's a shame the rest of the game cant' be of the same quality. 

Finally, destructibility and levolution. 2042 features a pitiful amount of destructibility for a Battlefield game. Very, very few walls/floors anywhere in the game can be destroyed with explosions. Levolution is present only on some of the maps, and most of the time you wont't even see it because it barely affects gameplay. Remember in BF4 when an entire dam would collapse and flood the map? Or when an entire skyscraper would fall and the rubble pile became the new objective? Well in 2042, sometimes a small piece of a freighter ships hull falls over and makes one new opening to an objective point. Or sometimes a tornado spawns and rolls right over only one objective on the map and disappears. The levolution is very boring and gets lapped by BF4's levolution, a game that came out over 10 years ago.

I thought I was going to be one of the cool kids who left a review whining and moaning about how this isn't a traditional Battlefield game and blah blah blah, but instead I actually have pretty positive feeling towards this game. Ultimately, it feels like a pretty good adaptation of a Battlefield game, but not all the way through. The option to mod guns in combat, use weapons across all classes, and the implementation of operator-specific abilities is WEIRD but not BAD. If this would have been marketed as an all new franchise it probably would have been well-received. Here are some things I noted:

Gun play? Really good, satisfying. Weapon customization in combat is... different but kinda cool.

Operators are fine, but they should not be able to be on both teams, really weird idea. Have 2 operators with same abilities, but one for each faction. Seems like a corner that was cut.

Operator abilities are fun, not game-changing for the most part.

Vehicle variety is nice.

Portal. Wow. Being able to play on a Bad Company 2 map with the classic guns makes me so unbelievably happy. It takes me back to early mornings when I would sneak onto my XBOX 360 just to play a match before heading off to school.

In conclusion, the game is not traditional, but not bad. I know it had launch issues and such, but now that it goes on sale for roughly $11 USD, it is totally worth picking up. If you are a Battlefield purist, stick to BFV; if you are willing to try something new, check it out.

If you're unaware of what battlefield is, its basically like call of duty on a large scale: 32 people on each team are placed on massive scale maps and have the objective of capturing flags. In other words everyone roleplays as those background characters that die immediately while the 5 people who have an ungodly amount of time in FPS games roleplay as the protagonists with actual dialog and meaningful impact 

This game is pretty much as fun as I remember the betas being so for $10 its not terrible 

But there are some glaring issues: 

-The game crashes a LOT, especially if you have a select amount of random programs open (it appears discord is a huge no no with 2024????) 
-Theres some major network issues on the 64 v 64 mode 
-General performance stutters in some spots 
-Theres this weird thing where if you're on the losing team you get spawn camped a lot 

But on the flip side it appears this game isnt plagued by some other industry standard garbage that made me lose interest in FPS games many moons ago like skill based matchmaking 

So win some lose some. As someone whos a more casual gamer these days and bought for $10 well after the rocky launch I think this game is pretty okay if you're good with just accepting you're going to lose sometimes

Should I spend 0.4 more hours and end up voiding my refund policy?

Edit: This game itself is OK, but on software perspective it is pure trash. I had to fiddle around to figure out how to fix being stuck in loading screen during my 1.6 hours playtime. Then, when I finally got into the game (I "fixed" it by relaunching multiple times), there is server issue where I always end up joining an empty server (the only way to fix this is by enabling crossplay). Even if there was a match, there are another two issues, I got kicked by no reason, and also performance is so bad. My character moves in slow-mo which is actually a global issue since 2 years ago. Finally, this game is online-only, so there is no way I can enjoy the game when the game itself is unplayable and doesn't have any singleplayer. Yes, I know it is advertised as multiplayer game, but my point is their server sucks.

Also, I actually notice this since BF4 when they updated the game having an in-game server browser. Since that day, BF4 starts to be unplayable sometimes. Perhaps it was the same issue brought forward into this one. I haven't tried BF5 yet.

^ This is what I put as my refund request for Battlefield 2042

(May 8, 2022): I think this game is a lot more worth it than it used to be. I was denied my refund request for this game and I've been playing on and off ever since but recently I've been playing a lot more. They did an update recently that fixed a lot of bugs, made the game's animations smoother and made the game run smoother all around. They tried to balance a few things, which worked in some ways and didn't in others. I still wouldn't pay full price for this game, but if you could get it for $30 or less, then I would say that would be a pretty good deal.

(February 8, 2024): This game is literally malware. They released a series of updates that has permanently ruined the performance for this game. For reference, I have a RTX 4090 and a Ryzen 9 7900x, so there should be no game under the sun that gives my computer a run for its money. However, this game stutters and has frame drops all the time and it doesnt happen on any other game. For some reason, this game just takes 100% of my CPU for literally no reason in the middle of a match. This has been going on for a lot of people for the past year or so, but it finally hit me and hasn't gone away after even uninstalls.

Man, I've been a huge Battlefield nerd since BF2. BF3 and 4 I played religiously back in highschool and always had a blast. 

This game has been out for several years and I figured it was worth a spin, right? I purchased it on sale and figured it can't be worth less than $11 of fun.

I played for just under 2 hours. Not because I planned to, but because it just felt bland and weird. I don't know how to quite describe it, but all of the action in the other battlefield games felt really cool, and small things from the movement, shooting, and just lack of interesting maps and environments made it feel like such a bummer to play. And I really, really wanted to like this game. I just didn't.

I used to like this game, it was fun, then I found myself lusting after a Linux only gaming system. Realizing the only thing keeping windows on my machine was this dogshit game that went from interesting shooter with cool ideas to a battlefield 4 clone that was a horribly optimized mess.

Do I miss it? Sometimes. Do I regret never being able to come back to it? Not at all. Its just a giant content farming simulator now. There's so many other interesting games that don't require half assed implementations or developers answering to a corporate agenda openly hostile to non bug eating pod living platforms. The Finals got Linux support before this game did. You can guess where all the talented DICE developers left to. And what games are really worth your time and money.

From someone that used to play Bad Company and some of the earlier Battlefields this is not a Battlefield game. The old games used to rely on Teamwork, especially medic roles. On the Conquest game mode there are limited lives per team but if you go down you can get revived and you don't lose a ticket. People don't bother and just re spawn automatically or if they're a medic just run past you. People focus on kills solely by running in constantly and dying and it just fills like a pumped up COD. There hardly any destruction mechanics that Battlefield was known for. 

It can be fun if you're playing with friends so there is that Team aspect or if you want to join in with the kids that are just playing a larger version of COD. Otherwise, just buy on sale or other methods... Full price is NOT worth it.

There isn't much to hate anymore. Feels like Battlefield, plays like Battlefield. Except the operator style classes with individual skins, but it is what it is, monetization isn't what it used to be. But hey, at least they don't go balls to the wall with the skins like Call of Duty. Still feels immersive. Quite frankly I don't understand the haters, do they expect a AAA shooter like this to not have modern monetization? As long as it brings us more map and gun variety, I don't care, I'm not the one spending money on those skins.

Let's also remember that this game doesn't shove blueprints down your throat like CoD in order to make you buy them so you don't start at 0! There is an Elite edition, but from what I understand it just unlocks operators and guns, doesn't actually give you attachments, you have to earn those yourself. 

I payed 14 bucks and for a great Battlefield game and I'm enjoying myself. Most of the reviews are outdated, the game is definitely worth it, especially for a sale price.

The game slaps. Idk who's idea it was at Dice and EA to have a bot mode, and allow us to gain XP playing the mode, but seriously, hats off to you. Even at a slower rate, it's so nice to level up and unlock stuff while playing a casual game. I don't play bots in any other shooter, but with the large scale battles here, it feels pretty good (even if the AI is dumb as hell). 

With that being said, my main complaint with this game is the specialists. Idk why they went that route, it's boring and restrictive, I don't know anybody who likes that. Let us create our own character, even if it's very basic, and have us play that character across each class. Sell us skins only seperated by male & female, I think that would make the game much more immersive and just make more sense. It kills the fun knowing theres 30 Boris' and 20 of each other specialist running around, very bad idea. 

I think the ship has sailed on full-price purchases, just let the game go F2P. Take out the specialist stuff, let us make our own operator, open the flood gates via F2P and go on a heavy promotion campaign. The core gameplay here is good, but it's plagued by a terrible launch and lingering bad decisions they just don't want to let go of for some unknown reason.

At the end of the day, 12 bucks or less on sale is a big recommend. Online is fun, once the sweats chase you out, bots are a lot of fun too.

Edit- 1/31/2023

The class update (Patch 3.2.0) REALLY ruined the good charm the game had, it SEVERELY hinders player choice, recon class is a very selfish class in this update, they can't do any-kind of useful team assisting activities, no giving ammo, no giving med boxes etc, you must conform to the new class rules and you must use selfish equipment that only helps yourself as a recon.

Whoever thought of restricting the ammo create and medical crate to just the support class and making the players pick ONLY one or the other has got to be in assisted living conditions to come up with that kind of "team assisting" mechanic there, the funny thing is the player that picks the support class could outright run a smoke launcher and ignore the calls for medics and ammo, meanwhile being the sole providers of it to the entire team.

This is supposed to be somehow help team play and be better than what we had before, which was the ability for you to pick the operate you liked and tailor your kit to better suit your play style which would help the team. This class update destroyed that.

Prior to this update, and dating back to launch, my review was "Recommended".
After this update I cannot suggest the game to anyone, it will remain "Not Recommended" until these changes are rolled back.

Edit- 1/5/2024

Nearly a year ago they released the class update which made balancing absolutely trash, prior you were able to use the character of your choice and craft their loadout into many different styles to help the team, I ran a recon character which I would use very aggressively due to their AOE scanner, I ran ammo box and LMG and restocked the team assisting in pushing and flanking, today it's impossible to play that aggressive without having a dedicated support player shadowing you restocking you or you will burn through the two magazines you're given unless you run out into the open and grab some ammo off a body due to not being able to run an ammo box on any character anymore, somehow this helps the team play though they claim, 2042's lack of class restrictions that it released with was truly the best change they made to the series, shame its lost.

Contrary to popular beliefs, Battlefield 2042 is a thoughtful and decently-well engineered first-person tactical shootah, in which you take the role of one of the various awperators at your disposal, and take part in large-scale modern warfare in a semi-futuristic-realistic setting of our nefarious modern society. While this is an EA title (yet again), you will be confronted to various micro-transactions options that will try to lure you into acquiring copious amounts of shiny pieces of equipment that provide no particular competitive advantage to its holder. While they may look good at first glance, I do not recommend you sinking your pound sterling into such gimmick created by multinational companies of such "AAA titles".

2024 review: 
The game is now fixed. Obviously it needed another 2 years cooking and was rushed so badly but now it actually looks and feels like battlefield again. If on sale for more then 50% off I would say its worth it now.

Where to start? Not many maps, if i'm not mistaken this is the bf with the lowest amount of maps EVER and they are releasing the newer ones at a slow pace.... why? Simple they are trying, TRYING (on the succeeding part...) to make the original works. And they don't... or  better they kind of do on Conquest but on Breakthrough every single map has some horrible point. Last point of Kaleidoscope, last point on Discarded and Exposure too. Who thought about stuffing 64 players in 10 meters was a good or even SANE idea? Manifest is Makay hunting ground (on reddit i read a comment that said it felt like Arnold fighting the Predator. TRUE) and to be fair various specialist just break the game. The best map are unironically the ones that comes from the older bf games like BC2 or BF3. Bf 2042 has quite possibly THE WORST map design i have ever seen in a FPS EVER, all the other Bf titles had some very solid maps and some bad ones but this bf has only examples of the latter. AH yeah and conquest the 64 player mode is the only viable the 128 is a mess in just about everything, with the worst hitreg i have ever experienced.
Weapon balance is inexistent with the VHX ( battlepass weapon go figure huh?) being so broken that it single handedly makes every smg bad. Its basically and AR made for close quarters with a HS modifier that is straight up BETTER than all the smgs... Why? 
Hitreg is quite bad too but not always, play 5 min in a match and see for yourself if its worth finishing it or just quit and find a match where hitreg actually works.

Graphics and audio are quite good as always has been in the saga but when you fail so hard at what is actually important for an FPS (map design, weapon balance and actually having a decent feedback when you kill someone) can this game be considered good? I don't think so but at least it's not infected with cheaters like its 2 predecessors so if you really miss BF try this one i guess.

You know carnival? Well, this is a Carnival Battlefield or something we can call the Fortnitefication of Battlefield. Tanks with red Christmas skins, Soldiers with yellow or pink weapon skins and gear. All you want here. And with it the game loses its last bit of seriousness. It’s just one big joke of a game when it comes to the scenario and the stage it plays on. Just seeing your colorful squad at the start and end of the round, reminds me constantly that I am fighting with a bunch of clowns, nothing else. 

Also considering that most available and offered skins are quite unrealistic when it comes to a military camouflage, you don't have much of a choice. If you want a skin, you need to take the colorful Dice and EA throws at you. Or should I say put in your face? Because the next big pain point I had with the game is the season pass upsell; you really need to dismiss the shit upsell page each game launch before you can even play or access the game. That is a new level for a full price Battlefield. 

Now you might wonder, why did he still play over 100 hours? Infact the run and gun play is still good. Graphics are OKish for a modern AAA game, though some elements feel like a downgrade to its predecessor. Then again the sound mix up is a blast! It’s just some much fun to play while rockets and grenades hitting around you and give you a never seen before bass on your ears. Generally I do believe the sound mix up is one of the big strengths of the game. Also if you are not into BF3 or BF4 anymore but still want a kind of modern warfare battlefield scenario, that is not tactical at all and has most of it (ground & air vehicles), then there is not much else than Battlefield 2042 out there. 

I played the Open Beta and discarded the game. But Dice has done a jump to fix the game and bring it from a quite bad game to a OKish one if you play alone and a solid one if you play with friends or good team mates. Because, that essence Battlefield 2042 has luckily; this game is such much better with a good squad…

Why?

Pros:
- Good variety of maps on some game modes
- lots of cosmetic content
- good amount of guns and gadgets
- the core battlefield experience is there
- vehicles are OK
- UI in game (when playing) is ok, the ability to swap gun parts is a nice touch.

That seems like a solid pros list doesn't it. However there is a but to all of them and many of cons themselves.

Cons:
- most NEW maps are either uninspired or badly designed. Throwing a tornado into a map does not make it better. Having spawns that do not take into consideration enemy captured points do make it miserable.
- lots of PAID cosmetic content - your usual battlepasses and what not. Some of it's ok some of it's not, mixed bag as usual.
- most guns play the same unfortunately. All boils down to DPS and what you managed to unlock the most. Most gadgets and abilities are actually useful but why not give players a freedom to mix and choose? Only the class designer can tell, especially when anyone can carry any gun.
- back to gadgets/items - if you have multiple AT launchers why not have a more detailed breakdown of their usefulness? Why do I learn useful tips about them from a loading screen. Is RPG stronger than the basic launcher? Do I have time to test it? Should I go on a wiki to find it out? Irritating to myself and this scenario applies to few more gadgets. In general the information about them is not presented in a clear way.
- core battlefield experience is there but it's only fun for maybe 25-30 hours. Then you might realise it's something you played before but this time it's not as much fun or polished and all the little details get in the way such as horrible UI or bizzare rubber banding in bigger servers.
-UI - could not make it harder to navigate menu and find information. Want to swap a gun mid match but not sure which option is better? Well get ready to click way too many times and be prepared to memorise the stats so you can compare them.
- flying vehicles are painful on mouse and keyboard, gamepad is a must.
- AA Vs helis/jets can be either a fantastic experience or a complete mess, especially if you are on foot with a very underpowered AA launcher.
- Sniping is underwhelming so are the LMGs. Other methods of fighting as mentioned before are ok but extremely repetitive.
- no tutorial or a training map and if it's there then golly i could not find it.
- bizzare character writing - I understand a lot was changed to the game in that regard but reading the character cards or the loading screen trivia is just painful. Cramming all that exposition into each charactet to make them cool is just bizzare and badly done. Classic example of let's have an X amount of characters that have to tick this list of 'cool' features. 

That's it. It could be great but it will never be. Let's wait for another one.

The game is more on par with that of a beta, I wouldn't recommend anyone buying it. The hit regulation is broken, the UI is missing a lot of elements, and the maps lack any creativity. It's a bland attempt at a battlefield game. The price on the game isnt worth it, it's lacking a ton of content. I'd wait for everything to be fixed and refined before purchasing.

02/02/2024:
Game still doesn't have a dedicated server browser, you'll only have access to a server browser for custom experiences. Soldier spawns are still nonsensical, it will constantly spawn you into the middle of a firefight and you'll die instantaneously. Rockets still don't register on air vehicles, and will usually fizzle out on impact. Weapon balance doesnt make sense, there's always one weapon per season that out does all the others. Hit registration bug is still rampant, your shots will not register on enemies due to terrible netcode. Do yourself a favor and avoid this game like the plague, there are no good times to be had here, most lobbies are full of bots, its a dying game. 

05/19/2023:
Game net code still doesnt function properly and is inconsistent to all hell, hit regulation is purposely being manipulated to benefit console players, more than half the time your bullets dont register on console players, while their hits register much faster on you if youre on pc. The multiplayer has no skill based matchmaking, and matches will always be once sided, RARELY will you be in a balanced match, their anti cheat is a joke. The map design makes no sense and will leave you frustrated. Dont buy this game, not even on sale, RUN FAR AWAY FROM THIS. I play this sh*t show so you dont have to! Ill update again once the next season is up.

03/10/2023:
Game is in better shape than it was at launch, however, the game still doesn't function very well. Weapons are unbalanced, hit registration is awful, and the map design is barren and pretty terrible. Spawns don't work, so don't be surprised if you spawn in front of enemies, vehicles stats are disproportionate to rocket damage, so vehicle camping is a huge issue. I wouldnt buy it, whatsoever, there are better military shooters out there with better dev teams and mechanics. I recommend you wait for it to be free through PS Plus/Xbox Live, because judging from what the devs have stated, there isnt a high probability that they'll adding more content after season 4.
It's been updated to the point in terms of play style, performance and content that it should have been much earlier on. It's definitely a fun game right now.

Its alright but its no battle field if you ask me, its acting like cod and mimicking it to say the least. That said the developers have worked hard to steer it in a good direction.  So Credit where its due I suppose. I have to say as a long time battle field fan its hard to play it sometimes because its not battle field at all.

My favorite feature of this game is the respawn roulette where when you press spawn you have a 50/50 chance of instantly dying to the 8 enemies you spawned in front of without any nearby cover to save yourself. Thanks for the surprise mechanics, we love those.

Balance of the game is atrocious helicopters are way too overpowered and are getting buffed while their counters are getting nerfed. The air supremacy not being helped by the maps (almost all of them) complete lack of cover). It is a common sight to see someone in an helicopter going 100-0 in score, "it's hard to play" isn't an excuse if once mastered there is no countering it.
There's a huge disparity in weapons balance with assault rifles beating everything else in 99% of scenarios. There is only one secondary weapon (G57) and everything else is a downgrade. 
Maps are flat with no cover, 3 of them have a boat theme yet we don't have a single water map. 
There is no singleplayer campaign or even singleplayer content at all meaning this game will inevitably be wasted space in your library when multiplayer dies and servers shut down.

Now the positives : 128 player mode makes the game more team-based and fixed base spawnkilling from previous games, the gunplay is fine, if there is no helicopter main (in either team really) it's a pretty good battlefield experience.

I simply cannot recommend this game as long as maps are not fixed with more covers and helicopters are brought down to a reasonable level.

I'll give this review as much love and thought as the devs gave to the game at launch and the months after that by asking chat-gpt for a review:

"""
As a long-time fan of the Battlefield franchise, delving into Battlefield 2042 felt like stepping onto a minefield rather than a battlefield. Dismal, disappointing, and downright disastrous, Battlefield 2042 fails on almost every front, tarnishing the once-glorious reputation of the series.

First and foremost, let's address the elephant in the room: the bugs and glitches. From game-breaking crashes to laughable physics, Battlefield 2042 is riddled with technical shortcomings that make it nearly unplayable. The sheer number of issues is astounding, leaving players frustrated and bewildered as they navigate through a virtual world fraught with inconsistencies.

Moving on to gameplay, Battlefield 2042 feels like a Frankenstein's monster stitched together from various uninspired ideas. The absence of a single-player campaign is a glaring omission, stripping away the immersive narratives that once made Battlefield titles stand out. Instead, players are thrust into a chaotic multiplayer experience that feels more like a beta test gone wrong than a polished product.

The maps, touted as sprawling landscapes ripe for epic battles, fall short of expectations. Rather than feeling expansive and immersive, they come across as empty and lifeless, lacking the intricate details and strategic depth that defined earlier iterations of the series. Coupled with lackluster level design and uninspired objectives, the maps in Battlefield 2042 feel like forgettable placeholders rather than memorable battlegrounds.

Furthermore, the introduction of specialists, a departure from the traditional class system, only serves to dilute the core gameplay experience. Instead of fostering teamwork and cooperation, it fosters a sense of isolation and detachment, as players struggle to find their niche in a sea of generic characters with little to no personality or depth.

And let's not forget about the monetization model, which borders on predatory. From overpriced cosmetics to pay-to-win mechanics disguised as "convenience features," Battlefield 2042 shamelessly prioritizes profit over player satisfaction, turning what should be a thrilling gaming experience into a shameless cash grab.

In conclusion, Battlefield 2042 is a train wreck of epic proportions, a soulless husk of a game that squanders the legacy of its predecessors in a misguided attempt to reinvent the wheel. With its myriad technical issues, lackluster gameplay, and shameless monetization schemes, it's a slap in the face to fans who expected better from one of gaming's most beloved franchises. Save your time and money and steer clear of this disasterpiece.
"""

From Fumbled Launch to Fun-Filled Frenzy

Battlefield 2042's launch was a rough one, riddled with bugs, balance issues, and missing features. But let me tell you, this game has come a long way, and it's now a blast to play.

DICE Hasn't Abandoned Ship

They've been steadily rolling out updates, fixing bugs, tweaking balance, and adding new content. Season 6 brought back the classic class system, a welcome change for many fans. And Season 7, just around the corner, promises even more: exciting new maps, fresh weapons, and innovative gadgets.

Is it perfect? No game is. But Battlefield 2042 offers a unique brand of large-scale, chaotic fun that you won't find anywhere else. Imagine 128 players clashing on vast, dynamic maps, with tornados ripping through the battlefield and sandstorms obscuring your vision. It's exhilarating, strategic, and often hilarious.

Here's why Battlefield 2042 is worth considering, especially on sale:

Redemption Arc: The game has demonstrably improved since launch, with ongoing support and content drops.
Classic Battlefield Feel: The return of the class system in Season 6 is a big win for fans.
Massive Scale: 128-player battles create unforgettable moments of chaos and teamwork.
Constant Evolution: Season 7 promises exciting new content, keeping things fresh.
Unmatched Fun Factor: If you crave large-scale, sandbox-style FPS action, Battlefield 2042 delivers.

To Buy Or Not To Buy

If you can snag it on sale, absolutely. Just be aware that it's not a perfectly polished experience. But if you're looking for a unique and evolving FPS with tons of potential, Battlefield 2042 is worth a shot. Just strap in, hold on tight, and prepare for an unforgettable ride.
Remember, Season 7 is just around the corner, bringing even more content to the table. So, buckle up and get ready for some epic Battlefield moments!

Re-revise - I've discovered that the root cause of the constant crashes and inability to play the game are a result of my own hardware setup. After much research and trial and error, I've discovered that the i9 13900 series of processors doesn't play well unity 5 and certain other games when coupled with a 40 series gpu. After disabling XMP and reducing clock speed of my ram to 4800 MHz from 6300 MHz, I also underclocked my CPU using the Intel XTU, from x55 down to x50, which seems to have resolved all issues with the game. It wouldn't be fair of me to negatively rate this game based on an issue outside of their control, I assume.

Editing review: Despite the good that this has to offer, I'm forced to change to a negative review. Recently, I've been absolutely plagued with tech issues. Seems that after each update for the past few months, I have to jump through hoops to play the game. Now, I'm getting a constant "out of memory" error when I launch or as soon as I enter a game. Needless to say, the issue is not my computer. The only other game that I've run into similar issues with is The Finals, in which I had to force the game to launch in dx11, downclock my CPU with Intel ETU, among other things. I'm not willing to go through this much trouble to play a game anymore.

TLDR; I truly believe that BF2042 is a very enjoyable game, even comparable to BF3 and BF4. I have hardly run into any bugs, weapons feel great to handle, and graphics are very attractive. The only major issue that I've run into recently is with the lack of players online at any given time. Several TDM sessions only had ~10 players, 3 on one side, and 7 on the other. Other sessions would randomly have a lobby filled with AI. I personally believe this to be an issue with the player base, in which most assume that this game is "bad" due to state of release. IMO, it feels very similar to any other BF title.

After 200+ hours of play time, and even more time spent on BF3 and BF4 (consoles/EA launcher) - this is as honest of a review as I can give.

Initially, this game was a hot mess. I logged in during the open beta to see what I could expect and was promptly greeted with repulsive bugs, game-breaking latency issues, and features that didn't make sense at the time.

After the beta, I decided to give Dice some time to iron out some of these problems, and I'm glad I did. Aside from constant issues logging in, (Every time I launched, the game would simply get stuck on the initial loading screen without any text or UI to indicate that it is loading, so I would need to re-launch the game to get in. Every time. This has been fixed as of season 5 however) the game was much more polished in many ways. I experienced fewer bugs, much more stable play sessions with fewer crashes and latency spikes, and the features began to make more sense as they improved them, or maybe, as I began to understand them. My major complaint at this point was the lack of options for weapons. 

After a relatively short hiatus, I came back to season 5 and 6. Season 6 introduced a new issues in which my game kept crashing due to what I assume is a driver issue or some kind of corruption of local files. After updating my drivers and verifying game integrity, the game continued working. 

At this time, the game has many options for weapons, though they have loosely re-implemented the class system by giving specific bonuses to weapon types depending on your class (Assault class gaining more ammunition when using assault rifles, medic class gaining fast weapon switching (iirc) when using sub-machine guns, etc), a change that I welcome, but it doesn't feel as free as it did before. Point being, the game certainly feels improved and gives me the same satisfaction that I once felt when playing BF4.

All in all- I haven't been able to understand the claims made by a majority of the player-base. Some claim that bolt action snipers are overpowered and are a 2-hit kill, but this was also true in other BF games (Especially in hardcore servers, in which any sniper rifle was a 1-hit kill). Others claim that the game "looks bad", but then are happy with graphics of games like Battlebit. Most of the negative reviews don't contain any helpful information as to why it was negative to begin with, and those that do seem only to mention technical issues- but that, I can certainly understand. I suspect I simply haven't had as many tech issues as most others. I believe my experience with BF2042 to be largely positive - I've had many hours of enjoyment and hope to have many more.

Disclaimer:
Unlike many of you, I carefully consider and respect the criteria set by the Steam review system when answering the question, "Do you recommend this game?" In my evaluation, I find this game deserving of a recommendation. The presence of exceptional graphics, well-crafted mechanics, immersive sound design, a reputable franchise, and consistent content support contribute to my affirmative response—100%, without hesitation.

However, it's essential to acknowledge another aspect, unrelated to my recommendation, that prompted the creation of this system. In comparison to Battlefield 5 or Battlefield 1, I would not recommend this game unless you have a particular preference for the modern warfare style. While Battlefield 2042 is a well-rounded game, some of its predecessors excel in core elements, making them, in certain aspects, even superior choices.

627 hours into the game and I still cant get over how bad the mechanics of the game are. Zone Spawning means you're gonna get cornered and farmed. No Switch Teams button, which hurts the player base when you have a Attack/defend game mode and the attacking team is paired with vehicles while defenders do not. Every patch that comes out, a new gun breaks the game and takes on average 3 months for devs to fix. Poor maps and game play. Some maps are either too big for the game mode or too small. Majority of maps offer only 3 avenues to approach to the halfway point (funnels team into getting farmed) or restricts game play and ability to change the map to fit tactics. instead you're forced to push through and play without any real tactics. Just shoot rockets and smokes and you'll win every game.  Levelution is extinct and the only few map changes that can happen is the weather. No nighttime maps or level changing events like the trailer shows. Specialists ruined the core game play that Battlefield survived on for so long. Every specialist gizmo pulls you out of the game loop and ruins moment. Certain specialist are broken or even way too OP and can practically ruin a fight. Last;y, the community has gone to crap. no more do you find people wanting to squad up, help each other or even giving some slack to new players. More often you're gonna find seal clubbers, max ranked, using said broken guns, specialists, and map advantage/disadvantage to go 150 -3 and then say your crap when he had to sit still and hold the trigger. I do not recommend this game nor the developers anymore, I'm genuinely worried for the next battlefield game. If its even gonna be battlefield anymore. Vehicles will either sit in their spawns to save themselves or do little to no damage and are just worthless and a place marker in the menu cause they couldn't get them right. RIP Battlefield, you will be missed. (Just not this one)

This game has swollen my nut sack to the point of overcoming testicular cancer. before i played this game I was a boy but because of the experiences I have had in this game I have become a man. I will never be the same I was a weak minded Yugioh card player for 11 years. i wen't to all the events and wasted thousands of dollars buying the full Exodia card combination but after finding a lump on my sack one day while setting up for the Yugi convention I had to visit a doctor and got the news that changed my life forever. I had testicular cancer in my left nut and was going to die if something wasn't done. Surgery was scheduled and I had my left nut removed which in turn lowered the amount of testosterone my body produced. My wife got me this game from walmart whilst I was healing from my surgery. Every respawn every life I could feel the vibration of life and death itself as my single NUT synchronized with the vibration of the controller in my hands I healed in less than three weeks and was back to my Day job at Dollar General where I work as a cashier. I shared my story with a few co-workers and one of my managers (Tony) whom I have grown fond over the years. The only real issue I have with the game is that there isn't a role-play mode. I feel like meeting up with other players on the map and expressing ourselves through emotes (which the game should already have..) like fortnite for instance would be really cool. maybe they could also add trans/furry costumes for characters with customization for character Bio like for instance "Character bio: Dark wolf ogre, Selfish, Sweet, Shy," anyway I love this game! 4/10 could have done better...

**A couple years later, and the game is what it should have been on launch.  Although now it's going down the CoD path of Seasons, Battle Passes, Lootboxes, and any other way they can make the UI a complete disaster.

Overwatch, Fortnite, and Call of Duty had a baby and this is the result.  The game can be fun to play, but it is not Battlefield--or at least I hope this isn't the direction the franchise is going.  Any of the old Battlefield games are superior in nearly every way.

Indisputable steps backward from even Battlefield 3, let alone 4+
-No scoreboard
-No player stats
-No game-wide chat
-Clunky UI and menu system
-No true 3D spatial/positional audio
-Destruction is inconsistent
-No filters for joining matches, with the exception of 'portal' mode
-No permanent Rush or other game modes

Other negatives
-Specialists are the antithesis of Battlefield franchise.  They feel like something out of Overwatch or Fortnite.  Not even CoD has something this cheesy.
-You can switch most of your loadout on the fly
-The maps are big just to be big.  There is a ridiculous amount of deadspace in between the objective sites on most maps.
-Graphics are mediocre at best, but will tax your computer as if they are state of the art.
-The dynamic environments aren't.

*Countless game-breaking bugs, though to EA/Dice's credit they are slowly getting patched:
-Stuck firing
-Stuck looking up
-Audio looping
-Launching out of vehicles across the map
-Vehicles falling through map
-Countless animations messed up
It's worse again.

This game is not ALL trash. It serves as a good blueprint on how to ruin a good franchise.

After a year of not playing I went in and tried every game mode, I was the only person on queue and had a whole server to myself.

This WAS a good franchise that got better and better with each release... that ended after Battlefield 4 (the best). They had to kill the Battlefield 4 servers to get the player base to move to the other games.

They went woke and went broke. Diversity Equity and Inclusion visible in the soldier classes. For example: Instead of adding 3 different gadgets to the medic class, they added different medics of different ethnicity. genders, whatever-you-call-it.

Months in, several patches layer, and the game is still unplayable.  I have not yet finished a single round start to finish without it crashing to desktop. 

The UI is the worst I have ever seen. Gameplay is terrible and clunky, the maps are boring and there are only like 3 of them, the vehicles are not fun to drive, gunplay is just bad. 

All around an awful experience.  100 dollars wasted. 

Edit:  31 hours in now, I keep trying to give it a second chance.  It no longer crashes, it it pretty stable, and runs decently on my computer.  

But, it's still not fun.  The maps are limited, and I have no favorite map because all are actually pretty terrible, and it still feels like I'm playing one of three or four maps every single time I load in.  I am disappointed every single time I load the game.  

I would not recommend this game even if it was free - it is not worth the hard drive space.  I will also never again buy another Battlefield title.  The only reason I keep trying to like it is because I loved the previous titles.  This is NOT a Battlefield game.  It has basically nothing in common with previous titles.  Battlebit is significantly closer to Battlefield than this garbage.  

I have given it like 50 tries.  I am now uninstalling it.  Thanks for lighting my 100 dollars on fire, jerks.
