OK, so, originally did the early beta access on Xbox Series S. Was definitely let down at that time and cancelled the pre-order. Fast forward to now, played the 10 hour trial on PC, they've definitely worked hard to fix the game. Game came up on sale for about $28 for me. Picked it up, and it's worth the price. They definitely need a bigger map selection for the 2042 side of things. I will mention the bugs they've fixed that i've noticed while playing in the pros section.

PROS:

They've fixed hit registry. (bug fix)
Connectivity issues are almost resolved. (server issue fix)
Graphically it looks good. However still needs some polishing in regards to how good the graphics can be.
The map selection is ok (is also a negative. But replayability on the maps currently available on the 2042 side). 
Portal is ok. Alot of Zombies game modes along with grinding game modes for XP are there. Not the biggest highlight here.
Weapons and gameplay feel good. Definitely something to adjust to. (to a degree.)
Is worth the buy at a discount (50% or greater discount. Or at or below $30.00)

CONS:
Not worth full price (at the time of review it is $64.99-$120.00 based on edition)
Map selection needs to be expanded. 
More needs to be done to help with spawn trapping. BUUUUUUT we all know that's an impossible task.
Noticable FPS drops during storm events. Haven't dropped below 40fps but went from 140fps to 50fps when the storms appeared on the map.
Operator selection is eh. Definitely would've preferred the old Battlefield Classes over the ops. Granted their abilities are entertaining (Can anyone say Blitz from R6S?).
Their most recent map is fairly broken with ways to glitch to opposite end of the map currently being used for conquest. Not really the funnest thing ever to suddenly get shot through a wall then someone glitching right into existance. 
Need to launch the game twice for it to function. I'll re-review this in a bit if they can patch these issues up.

I spent countless hours playing Battlefield games starting in the early days with Battlefield 1942 and peaking with Battlefield 3 and 4... I dabbled with Battlefield 1 but skipped Battlefield 5 all together. I was very excited that Battlefield 2042 when announced was headed back in the modern era as that is where my favorite games had been. It was very sad upon 2042's release that it got crushed by critics and Gamers alike. 

So now here we are 2 years after release and I read that the game was back on track and much more in-line with the games I really loved (Bad Company 1 and 2, Battlefield 3 and 4). So I grabbed the $10 Black Friday deal which definitely made it easier to try out and BOOM I was back in. I'm so extremely happy that, for me at least, BATTLEFIELD is back. I love everything about this game. I cant really put it into words but it scratches that itch that I have been missing for years.

If you haven't played this game since launch then you should definitely give it another shot. BF is back with the traditional concepts of 4 classes and fun gameplay that we all came to know and love in the past 1.5 decades of the BF franchise games. It's unfortunate that EA released this game (with many of the EA releases) was once again, not ready and felt botched. I gave up for a year and was gutted that they screwed up (again). However, the BF team stepped in and have in my eyes, redeemed themselves by bringing back the true nature of BF. If you already own this, give it another shot, do you have $15 to spend on an amazing FPS military BF game? Why not give it a go? It has well over $15 of content plus a highly immersive multiplayer. I love BF, and as jaded as I was over the launch, I gave it another shot after many things were fixed and I couldn't be happier that I did.

If you like playing as a sniper, seriously pass on this game.   The whole point of being a sniper is hanging back and doing long distance shots, helping with recon.  There is a character with a ghille suit, which I was really stoked about.  Problem is that the scope glint is so damn bright it's like putting a flashlight on the rifle, which defeats the whole point of the ghille suit.  It's ridiculously bright and stands out like crazy.   So much so it that it basically castrates the role of long-range sniper.  The most effective way to play the recon role is to run around and use the sniper rifle close-range like it's a damn shotgun.  It's so stupid.   If I wanted to do close range combat I'd play those roles.  I played a few other roles and it's mostly the same as the rest of the franchise.  Graphics are solid, gameplay is intense and fast but that's just not my gaming style.  So I guess to each his/her own.  It's just not for me as someone who has exclusively played recon for the most part.  I'll stick with BF4.

Get this on sale. 

This game at launch was awful. I bought this game 3 times, and refunded it twice. Oddly enough, third time is a charm. No more RNG recoil, I now get over 100 fps on high settings, maps have been reworked, you can level up your guns fighting bots to catch up, classes have returned, there is a scoreboard, and I am genuinely liking the characters (but not all of them).

It feels like this game has been in Early Access for the last 2 years, and has finally released. It's fun, and I have yet to have a dull moment with this game, but this should've been how it is on release, hence, this may not look good for the future of this game because it took so long to get stable. Also, it needs more maps, its pretty much a bare bones battlefield experience, which is ok by me since I paid only 10 dollars to play it.

I played BF2042 at launch, Season 3 and picked it up on Steam during Season 6. I have seen this game's progression over the last 2 years and i would say i can recommend it now. Yes there are a couple missing features like All Text chat, single player and remnants of the Operator system still in place but the moment to moment game-play is top notch and the best it has been. I prefer the movement we have in this game over past entries and any glitches and bugs seem to gone and the game has been running like a dream. The Redacted map introduced in Season 6 is basically BF2042's Nuketown/Shipment/Rust and is great for chaotic game-play and leveling up weapons.

Hopefully DICE continue the momentum and do another season beyond S6 (as we have had hints in dev streams).

(No I was not thinkning this would be call of duty) I had a monster KD every match I played, players literally feel like bots, no one is using coms.


Please return to former glory call of duty needs to be dethroned, and I want you too do it!!! I have nothing but high hopes for your next installment, this was just sooo generic feeling. Runs fine but the maps are designed absolutely terribly. Nearly every single point in breakthrough feels either super exposed or no room to move whatsoever. Some zones are single points with no nearby zones for defenders to spawn while others have attackers running 200m+ across flat land with no cover just to get close to site. Of the current 11 maps only 2 are decent, those being spearhead and manifest. Honorable mention to kaleidoscope for being the other playable map but it's still trash. 

Guns feel fine, recoil is fine but something I can't get over is bullet drop and damage drop. Why does my ak-12 drop several inches at 100m? Why do we have 308 or 54R LMG's dropping at the same rate? Why does my DMR take more shots to kill than my LMG at 100m? The best question I've got is why does the recoiless m5 have ranging lines on it that don't even line up? Bunch of complaints surrounding fighting at 100m+ but inside of that the game feels good.

IFF is a big problem as well, for some reason all characters on both sides look the same so there's no ability to tell at a glance if they're friendly or hostile. Would appreciate characters losing the skins for literally any ability to tell if they're hostile or not when I'm looking at them instead of looking for their name tag.Game runs fine though, only had one crash in 30 hours. Getting the game started through steam is an impossibility though. Gotta use the ea app or it shts the bed with a near 100% failure rate.

End of game and start of game animations need to be able to be cancelled, and need to be able to back out of the lobby during awards as there's a solid 40 seconds every post game where I just can't do anything and end up browsing yt or reddit or some other garbage site.

Avoided a purchase at launch because of obvious reasons
Avoided a purchase during the many "free" sessions because bugs were still a large part of the experience.

Decided that I had my fun with Battlebit but I missed the chaos and polish that previous Battlefield titles provided and I figured $12 for a shot at revisiting it was worth trying.

I'm glad I did. Game runs great, Sounds as good as always and in the few games I've played today I was immediately brought back to that feeling of enjoying Battlefield titles of the past. The game runs great (albeit it on a 4080 so ymmv), the sound design is always a pleasure (Thank you for continuing the trend of Binaural audio) and the gunplay felt immediately natural.

I say worth it because the winter sale is good - It'd be a hard pill to swallow at $60 but for a few more months of some somewhat mindless shooty times - It's a good way to enjoy some time.

So to start off I bought this game last year December during sales, therefore I didn't experience the whole lot of garbage that this game was at launch and some time post-launch. I did play it extensively when the devs really started "fixing" the issues, and I found the game to be decent and, for the time being, playable. I went through multiple seasons (end Season 3 to Season 6 now).

The GOOD. There isn't much to say of good things about the game. I could say that the devs really tried fixing things up, making up for the whole mess they gave at launch. They adapted the maps, gave more weapons, reworked the Portal guns by giving them the attachments from 2042 era, sort of gave the new "Metro/Locker BF4" map, Battlepass isn't really grinding. But that is bout it...

The BAD. There is a lot to say, but you probably have seen many YT videos and reviews. I really wanted to like this game at first, but after 289 hours of playing I finally came to the conclusion that this game will never be any good than even BFV. And I played a lot of BF titles, I have around 2k hours through Origin on BF4 (and that launch was horrible at the time). 

1) The classes: they sort of fixed them and gave back the " original design". But it's still shit as some of the operators are trash in comparison with the others that are OP. Yes, I am looking at you Dozer (the shield rework made him so much worse to play against). 
2) Weapon balancing: still shit. With the recent update they gave out VHX AR and EVERYONE was abusing it to the point where it became unbearable to play against anyone because the gun is broken. Also the attachments are garbage because you only need to use 2. 
3) The events and the rewards: none were actually good balanced from the beginning with the rewads being absolute disaster for the grind that you had to go through. Good example is the hyped up event with the AI where the maps were too big and the player count was too small. 
4) Vehicles: I hope that those vehicle players that spam the Premium Truck that is not balanced at all will get permanent brain damage as it's garbage. To this day I find it not worth your time learning how to play with the vehicles because you are either destroyed in seconds or obliterated by the sweaty nerds. 
5) Bugs and the performance: there are still bugs with the animations and the spawning where it blacks out your game, FPS is decent but not really good, the overall look of the game feels too simple. 

I am going to finish playing the game with the new season that the devs announced, but it might be the case where I will just uninstall and jump on more BattleBit as that game is the BF experience you wanted to have with no strings attached.

Fun at times, but mostly frustrating and boring game.

The only "good" new map was Redacted and even that gets boring eventually, everything becomes routine, min/maxed for the K/D farming. The other more recent Linearly designed maps are decent, most of the original launch maps are still pretty much a walking simulator with almost zero cover. The terrain elevation changes on all maps makes it feel like I'm constantly tripping on something.

Input feels weird, its very hard to describe but its at least "better" now compared to before. This input weirdness is more apparent with a faster 144hz display. Same with movement, it feels like you're constantly rubber banding. Essentially I don't feel "connected" with my character's movement.

Hit reg is still a freaking lottery. 2 times out of 10 your shots wont register. You can see this happen if you enable Event Log from the settings to compare hit regs seen by the client and by the server. This is despite having 30ms ping. The game feels worst to play in 128 lobbies, Its not frame-rate issues, its just makes the game feel more sluggish in regards to input.

I want actual class systems back. 

Lastly, the new anti cheat is useless. Here in the Asian region, we get rage cheaters very often.

Conclusion:
I love battlefield, and this was a big disappointment. 

This could have been great, but it wasn't. Season 7 is coming next year and that might make it fun again. Although I bet the majority of new "content" would just be another set of skins for battle pass players. Which i refuse to get due to the state of the game.

I don't think you can fix this game because it is definitely fundamentally broken to the core.

Would I recommend this? only if it's on heavy sale and if you're bored. Not the greatest Battlefield Game by any stretch of the imagination.

How they haven't fixed this in 2 years is pitiful.

Not at all a battlefield game. 
Pros:
- Fast paced
- Objective focused

Cons: 
- Almost zero destructible environmental objects
- Operators have special abilities that make the game play out like apex including people flying all over the place and getting on objects no one else can using the wingsuit just to camp with a sniper rifle
- A place able front shielded mini-gun turret is more powerful and more annoying than most vehicles
- Riot shields that are bullet proof nearly grant invincibility in CQC situations unless there is a teammate that conveniently gets behind them
- No weapons are class locked
- The only reason to play any of the classes is for their very limited amount of class specific field items
- Not a fan of a good number of the maps in game

Battlefield Bad Company 2 is Battlefield. EVERYTHING can be destroyed in that game (or rather could before it was recently completely shut down by EA). Each class had meaning and a role to fulfill, team coordination was important, and snipers provided great support by marking targets, providing supporting fire, and requiring a small amount of coordination from the enemy team to find and eliminate. 

2042 has NOTHING of what makes a battlefield game a battlefield game, and just feels like another generic FPS game much like the competition.

Never forget how EA and Dice consistently release broken horrendous games. 

However, 2042 is fun now. Most things are fixed and it's pretty well balanced. 

It isn't worth the full $60. It is worth $10.

I like many of you watched the decline of DICE and battlefield games. BF1's messy launch and re-balancing, BFV's messy launch, bad pr and, yet again, confusing balancing post-launch. Followed by BF2042's horrific launch and subsequent year plus of development time just getting the game to a playable state. All that being said, here we are entering 2024 and I have to say 2042 is not just a solid game, but is battlefield. The spectacle, the infantry and vehicle combat, the large scale teamplay, it's all there, and still nothing else comes close to the experience. Clearly, the game was designed by a committee of business interests rather than developers and is still full of half baked ideas that went nowhere (looking at you hazard zone). But the core gameplay loop is solid. I would recommend waiting for a sale due to the fact that this is the most content light BF game in a decade. DICE, please for the love of god, just make your next title a battlefield game, we dont need a shallow half baked extraction shooter, we dont need overwatch hero mechanics we just need you to deliver the  core battlefield experience that you are known for. Pick this game up on a sale, its absolutely worth 20 bucks.

Solid game.

Looks great, sounds great, feels good to play, and has enough in-game content to keep playing for.

Matches flow well on most of the maps (especially after the reworks) and the official game modes are as fun as they always are in a Battlefield game; not to mention the community game modes and classic maps offered on Portal.

Could there be more? Absolutely, with some shortcomings being more obvious than others.

For example, 2042 has a "story," the premise of which is intuitive to pick apart by just playing the game and listening to the US/Russian announcers. But if you want to know more about the lore, you have to read it, which most people aren't going to do because they bought a game, not a book. Without a campaign to tie all the lore together in an immersive and engaging way, the settings and contexts of the multiplayer maps feel disjointed. Which is a shame because a little bit of emotional stock in the matches could add so much more.

Regardless, the majority of the many things that this game DOES has to offer are satisfying, and that's what's important.

Many (though not all) of the negative reviews are from people who unfortunately prefer to be angry for the sake of it and to brood with the like-minded, rather than from a place of honest criticism. 2042's flaws are often over-exaggerated, so take the naysaying with a grain of salt.

Battlefield 2042 has proven to be a revelation for me, marking a significant leap forward in the realm of multiplayer shooters. The game introduces a fresh perspective, exciting innovations, and an incredibly immersive gameplay experience.
One standout feature is the stunningly realistic graphics and attention to detail. Virtual landscapes come alive under the influence of dynamic environmental destruction, creating a genuine sense of chaos on the battlefield. The weapons and vehicles are meticulously crafted, contributing to an authentic feel throughout the game.
The new specialization system and adaptable maps add strategic depth, allowing players to tailor their combat style. Engaging in massive battles on expansive maps enhances the overall scale and epic nature of the gaming experience.
Another notable aspect of Battlefield 2042 is its focus on social aspects of multiplayer. The "Portal" mode allows players to create custom scenarios using elements from previous Battlefield titles, injecting nostalgia and diversity into the gameplay.
I want to commend the developers for their ongoing support and updates. Regular patches addressing issues and improving game balance demonstrate a commitment to the player community.
In summary, Battlefield 2042 is an excellent addition to the legendary series, bringing a breath of fresh air to the multiplayer shooter genre. I highly recommend it to both genre enthusiasts and longtime Battlefield fans!

I'm new to 2042, but played nearly every previous battlefield game. I bought this game on sale for like $8.99. It feels like battlefield to me, it plays well. I haven't encountered any overt hackers yet, which is why i stopped playing BFV. Maybe the game was different when it was first released, but it seems pretty solid to me. I am STOKED I got it on sale, and I'm having a blast.

*Updated after 45 hours of play* 
I'm still loving the base game and I'm glad I didn't buy the battlepass or super deluxe edition. If you are halfway decent at FPS games you can unlock everything just by playing, I don't care at all about skins, it's a first person game except when you are dead and look at your body. If you have money to burn and are impatient, go for it, but for most people it's just unnecessary.

This game does have a slightly different feel than the other battlefield games, it's faster paced because of grappling hook dude and wingsuit dude. But overall it still feels like battlefield. It PLAYS like battlefield, the mechanics I enjoy are still there. Some guns are better than others, but most are pretty reliable. The default glock sidearm has a burst fire mode, it's awesome, I can saw down groups of enemies in ambushes. I like the differing classes with special abilities.

I understand a lot of people who purchased the game at launch might be salty if the game wasn't up to par then, I can't speak for that. The game RIGHT NOW, I'm having a blast. For me it's mindless team deathmatch 24/7. I don't care about any other mode. It's fantastic TDM. I haven't encounter a single 120-0 cheater in 45 hours of play. I'm not saying people don't cheat, people always find a way in online games. But it's nowhere near as overt as in BFV or others. I am really enjoying this game.

*200+ hour update*
I definitely have encountered a few obvious cheaters, but it's still significantly fewer than previous battlefield games. The matchmaking works well at this point, I usually don't have to wait more than 20 seconds or so for a match. 

Pro tip, if you want to quickly unlock weapons, start a solo conquest game with AI set to beginner on the map redacted. It's easy to get well over 150 kills in one round, it will unlock new weapons and attachments SUPER fast. I had already unlocked about 75% of the weapons, but once I figured out the solo conquest I was unlocking like 3 new weapons PER GAME. It's not necessary to unlock everything, but it helps for certain guns that are weak.
after 200+ hours I still really enjoy the game. I bought the game on sale for $9.99 I think and in the end I spent $20 on cosmetics, which bought me 2 uniforms for Falk, I usually play support. I really don't mind spending a little on microtransactions as the game is really fun for me.

The game runs REALLY smoothly too. I'm not sure if it's specifically because of DLSS, but the frame rate never dips.

Upon release, the game was indeed what the reviews may reflect. Yet even now we get negative ratings for a few reasons of unusual nature. The main issue others and myself have been experiencing, are the occasional lag / stutters which make your smooth aim snap across from the target and when combined with the method the game uses for hooking your cursor, it can be an unsatisfactory moment for many. The other major issue which my friends and I have been experiencing are the endless amount of low level cheaters. If these factors are overlooked by yourself, then the game will offer no more than the good old battlefield experience. Beware of the helicopter mains 

7.5/10

---------  xx/02/23  --------

Revising my initial review, I would like to emphasise the magnitude of the main issues. The biggest issue by far are the vehicles which you are unable to counter unless you are specialised in vehicle destruction which would take away your ability to efficiently kill enemies.

Helicopters are in fact where the main balancing issues lie, other vehicles are on the edge of balanced from what I've seen.

The other great issue is the aim assist on console... The aim assist is effectively aimbot and requires zero skill from the player as it traces the enemies inhuman-like. Yet when you turn off  cross-play, you will be unable to find a lobby of 128 pc players.

Battlefield 2042 is a fun fast paced shooter. Classes and equipment customizeable to adjust to your playstyle. 

This game doesn't feel like the previous titles. If you only played the previous BF, you will have to adapt to not go under in this one. The dynamic and faster gameplay, custom loadouts and classes pose quite a challenge for people that aren't familiar with similar games like apex or warzone. 

If you like a fast paced new BF experience similar to warzone, I recommend this one.
If you mainly wanna play the previous titles / mashups in Portal mode, get it on sale.

In 32v Conquest, you can also encounter previous battlefield maps, I recommend the smaller 32v Conquest mode for the maps and better performence.

I refunded this game on steam a couple months ago and got it on epic two days ago.
I got it on sale for $10 and for that price I would say it's worth it. There is still a lot of stuff that needs to be fixed such as:
Wing-suit feels clunky and doesn't feel good to control at times. 
The Helicopter and Jet controls feel terrible imo, it felt better with the planes in bf1. 
When in an elevator, your character starts going crazy, and you start moving all over the place. I keep crashing in the game after a couple matches. 
The ai is still not that great, I'm not good at fps games, and yet and I can go crazy in bot matches with the settings turned up to advanced bot level.
It is also very sad that the environments are indestructible, some parts of buildings fall off and break but it's not like the past games, hope they update it in later.

Battlefield 2042 has proven to be nothing short of a colossal disappointment, marred by glaring technical issues that make the game virtually unplayable. From the moment I attempted to launch the game, it became abundantly clear that DICE and EA had dropped the ball on this one.

The most frustrating aspect of Battlefield 2042 is the abysmal loading screen problem. It's not an occasional inconvenience; it's a pervasive and infuriating obstacle that plagues every attempt to enjoy the game. Waiting times are excruciatingly long, and the promised seamless experience is nothing more than a distant dream. It's unfathomable that such a basic component of gaming – launching the game – could be so fundamentally flawed.

The loading screens are not only time-consuming, but they also serve as a stark reminder of the lackluster optimization that went into this title. The game stutters and stumbles its way through the loading process, leaving players wondering if they'll ever get to experience the actual gameplay without interruption.

Adding insult to injury, when players do manage to overcome the loading screen ordeal, they are often greeted with a myriad of other issues. The gameplay itself is riddled with bugs, glitches, and frame rate drops that further detract from any enjoyment that might be salvaged. It's clear that Battlefield 2042 was rushed to market, sacrificing quality for a premature release.

One would expect a AAA title like Battlefield 2042 to have undergone rigorous testing and optimization before hitting the shelves, but the current state of the game suggests otherwise. This is not an acceptable standard for a franchise with such a rich history and a loyal fan base.

In conclusion, Battlefield 2042's laundry list of technical shortcomings, particularly the egregious loading screen problems and the overall issue with launching the game, make it impossible to recommend. Save yourself the frustration and avoid this broken mess of a game until the developers address these issues – if they ever do.

I like this game a lot.  I would love it a lot more if the bugs were fixed.  When I am in game and got a good score going I often lose internet connection and lose all that xp that I built up.  Switching weapons is also buggy.  I often end up in a firefight and get killed because the weapon button does not respond.  In order to like this game you have to realize that you start with weak ineffective weapons.  As you level up, you get better and better weapons.  Getting a battlepass is also important because you can earn better weapons.  Overall a good game.  If they could work out the bugs it would be a great game.  This game will frustrate you in the beginning.  Remember to hang in there and shoot as many as you can to build up your xp - even if you cant kill someone in the beginning, hitting them gives you an assist - xp - when someone else kills them.  Overall I recommend this game for people who are into first person shooters.

Updated. Gunplay is good, community is garbage.

Wanted to wait some time until EA/Dice could at least get a few patches in before the holiday season. At the moment I just can't recommend people playing this game unless they have absolutely nothing better to do. I will continue to log hours but without some major changes it will probably be put on the shelf until it gets to a more enjoyable state.

Lots of people will give the lack of "legacy" features as reasons they hate the game. But really people can live with no scoreboard and other quality of life issues in the short term if the rest of the product is good. Sadly the bad launch, numerous bugs, poor map design and poor performance are the main reasons for the reducing player base.

Specialist is a nice idea but no one asked for it however it does lead to some interesting game play but some of the less useful ones need some balancing or tweaks to that system all together.

Things I like:
128 players (I thought I would gravitate to 64 player servers but keep going back to the chaos that is 128)
Visuals
Gun Play (still some hit reg issues but that was massively improved)
Gun Balance (last patch they got this mostly right, most if not all guns are viable need some tweaks still)
Portal

Things I don't like:
Tornado/Dynamic weather - Do not believe the extent in which they planned for dynamic weather was worth the pursuit
Performance - Clearly needs optimization, very CPU intensive. Even close to min specs you will need a good CPU/Memory combination to get ~40fps on low. I was running a 1080TI + Ryzen 5 3600 and would get about ~55fps on low, 40fps on ultra. Now running 1080TI + Ryzen 7 5800x and get 90fps on low which is at least acceptable.
Maps - I think this has been mentioned a lot, if you are into infantry play most of the maps are not every enjoyable. 
Dice/EA Misled - Based on all of the hype for the game, the actual experience really doesn't match the cinematic videos they released leading up to the release of the game
No VOIP yet - This seems like a critical day 1 need... 

Will update my review down the road if they improve.

Don't believe all this hype and propaganda about how "Dice has put so much effort into making battlefield great" and "now it's awesome". It's the exact same as it was at launch minus some bugs LOL. Initial launch 

Is this playable as others have said? Yes. 
Does that mean it's good? No. 
It isn't battlefield that's for sure. This game has definitely lost its identity. The corner cutting in development and graphics, the features and QOL detriments Dice has made which deviate from Bad Company and BF4 are egregiously obvious. 

You'll run, maybe see someone and kill them, then die. It's the same trading mechanism over and over. You show up on the map, you die. You fire, you die.


Not many people use LMGs b/c they don't have a use in this. You're not going to be able to sit in a position and fire on people b/c as soon as you fire...multiple people see you or you get sniped. 

The vehicles are quite awful. Dice made an explicit focus of being vehicle centric in this version of battlefield, but what they neglected was the opposite side of using vehicles - destroying them. Shooting a vehicle with a rocket (aka recoiless rpg) and hitting yields "Vehicle Damage 20xp". Okay...so how much damage? Every shot is 20xp. That's it. 

One awful aspect about Bf4 was the flying exploits - aka the jets, little birds, and attack helis that could easily evade AA and rack up dozens of kills with very low, to no deaths. And this version is no different. A decent pilot is invincible. Doesn't matter if you use a recoiless, AA, the LIS...you get that stupid 20xp message for a hit and they just keep on going. 

I don't understand how such an obvious train wreck happens after BF5 then BF1...now this.

Feb 2023: Classes are back, specialists are still present however. Upon initial writing of this review I said there appeared to be a lack of teamplay and I still partially stand by this. While one could argue that the lack of class restrictions led to less teamplay, on the other hand one could argue that it can lead to more teamplay as you could pick whatever, do your thing, but still help out and not feel forced to play a Support character because everyone chose to play Assault and you're running low on ammo constantly. I've always been a Support and Recon main in previous BF entries. Infinite ammo and long range was my thing. This is a major change up of what was a CORE mechanic of the game, and I'm not sure if I agree with this. People say this will lead to more teamwork. Will it? I'm a Ammo man and Recon main, always have been. You CAN'T force me to play Medic or Engineer in ANY BF game, I play those when I want to, not at the request of anyone. You'll have to put class limit restrictions to stop me, like in BFBC2 with Recon limits, which didn't stop me from playing Assault and using a DMR or shotgun w/ slugs, while sitting at the back of the base. The decision to lock gadgets/throwables/specialists back to classes will only do one thing for me, and that is to make me play everyone EVEN LESS. Before, I could help destroy tanks and harass vehicles AND keep everyone topped up on ammo. Play as McKay, get to elevated places and resupply teammates who ran out of ammo. Irish APS for cover, repair tool to keep vehicles alive or set up a defensive position while capturing objectives and provide resupplies. Now? I'm not abandoning infinite ammo to destroy tanks. You may think "wow, you don't seem like a team player". Believe what you want but I'm an infinitely better Support player than you or most players will ever be, infinite ammo is my life. Hell, I've done more teamplay as an Assault player than 90% of assault players in BF4 by just reviving people. Quite frankly, I don't care about the team. Its a byproduct of me enjoying what I do which is having infinite ammo, and to shoot stuff. Jack-of-all-trades, master of none. I'd much rather be a master of my craft than a jack-of-all-trades. Limiting this freedom back to the four classes while still having Specialists is a weird move. I will continue to prioritize [b]MY OWN FUN FIRST[/b] before teamplay. Find someone else to assist you in destroying tanks because YOU CAN'T FORCE PEOPLE TO PLAY FOR THE TEAM. PERIOD.               

So anyway what are my general thoughts? As just a SHOOTER game, its satisfactory at best and I personally don't mind it, now that they've fixed a fair few issues and we're finally into Season 1 which took way too long. But as a BATTLEFIELD game, the hate train has left the station. In my opinion, had they called this game anything but Battlefield, hell call it Battlefield Heroes 2 since there already was a BF Heroes game, I would've been okay with it, but as a BF vet, this game has lost its identity. Battlefield was NEVER a hero shooter. It was NEVER a direct competitor to CoD. Only Post-BFBC2 "vets" call it a CoD competitor. Battlefield is its own thing NOT TO BE COMPARED. It didn't NEED to copy other games. Battlefield had its own identity, and tossed it away to appeal to god-knows-who and that was a mistake.

I won't go into details since literally every single person has talked about this game at this point. Because this game is now basically a hero shooter, teamwork more or less goes out the door. Despite the fact that ANYONE can revive (for all you dumb mofos, yes, you, playing Casper or whatever, can also revive SQUAD MATES) majority of the dumbasses in this game don't, either because they're braindead and don't realize ANYONE can revive squadmates or are too busy focusing on "being #1". Now that's not to say people don't revive, as I've been revived many times, but there have been MANY occasions where I die in cover, the area is safe, and MANY suitable people (support/squadmates) run by me as if I don't exist. This is the general mentality of BF2042, everyone for themselves. I don't need a Support player, I can just play Angel, I can bring my own ammo, I can pick up dropped ammo. I don't need a medic, I can just bring medbags, or I can play Falk. I don't need Engineer, lemme grab my launcher/repair tool while playing Angel. Recon? Lemme just get my sniper rifle, medbag, and play Angel, infinite ammo, health, and I can sit back at base and snipe. Teamwork is essentially gone. Vehicles? Pfffttt, who needs an Engineer or repair tool, my vehicle has a built in repair system anyways. It goes both ways, having this freedom CAN lead to more teamwork but it can also lead to less teamwork. It flip-flops from game to game.

While this sort of freedom to make almost whatever loadout you want is cool, it takes away what makes a BF game a BF game. Which is why I think if they called this game anything else (and slap "made by the devs of BF" on it) or even BF Heroes 2, I think it would've been a better decision which would've likely led to a better reception. The launch obviously was complete garbage and inexcusable, but once again, not here to talk about that, I'm talking about the core experience. At least that would at worst get a mixed rating IMO.

When they introduced Season 1, a new character with a player controlled MANPAT/MANPAD was added. It's like the SRAW from BF4 (closer to TV missile really) or the AT-4 from BFBC2. Except, because this rocket launcher is specific to the character and is a "special ability" you actually have INFINITE USE. You used up both rockets? Sit around and wait for the cooldown to replenish those rockets automatically. IMO this adds to the "play for yourself" mentality. Why go frontlines when I can just sit back and spam infinite guided rockets.

This game is by far the weakest entry of any Battlefield game if you can even call it a Battlefield game. "Oh but Hardline exists". Well, at least Battlefield Hardline had the SPIRIT of Battlefield, literally the only thing it was missing was the MILITARY theme. Outside of that, Hardline was more Battlefield than BF2042. Hardline was essentially a reskinned BF4. Thanks to DICE LA/Visceral or whatever they're called now. The same people who worked on Battlefield Portal which is about the only truly good thing about BF2042. They are the real heroes here.

They failed with this game and they've hurt the franchise. I'm concerned for the future of the BF franchise and what lies ahead because of this.

To sum up my general thoughts, if you overlook that this was supposed to be a Battlefield game, and treat it as "some generic FPS game", I honestly don't hate it. I'm somewhat neutral and my bar is fairly low for shooters. If its got guns that I like, good enough for me. Obviously there's more to it than that but you get the idea, I'm fairly easy to please when it comes to shooters. BUT AS A BATTLEFIELD GAME, you've seen the feedback from many others. I came for a BF experience that they advertised this as a "love letter to fans", but its more of a divorce letter.

Will I stop playing this game? Nah. Like I said above, if I ignore that this was supposed to be a Battlefield game, and just play it as "just another FPS game", its fine for me (huffing some copium), but for anyone looking for a [b]Battlefield experience[/b], go back to previous entries, this might not be worth it. Grab it on sale if you really want to try it or wait for a free weekend.

Incredibly poor in creativity, design, customization, weapons, and content. It feels like a downgraded version of the new CoD/warzone, and I'm a Battlefield fan. It surprised me how awful this game is. The characters are boring, uninteresting, and straight-up ugly (both in design and looks). The skins are downright poor and badly elaborated. The guns are ridiculous. They feel like cheap imitations, with few and rigid customization. The lack of content in the game is astounding, really. I saw videos and game plays before but I had no idea how awful it was until I got it and played it. To think that with time they would add a bunch of new, well designed, interesting stuff to the game is a sad expectation, because they basically didn't. A franchise this big, behind a company this powerful and rich, you'd expect a real game. A good game. And all we got was this piece of garbage. I shouldn't have given them my money.

I've played a lot of the Battlefield games and have grown a bit bored of the format.  But I was encouraged to give this one a go.

They say, don't bring support issues to reviews.  I have 2 hours to decide whether I want to keep a game or refund it.  After the lengthy download, I fired up a game to play with my squad, while they could all join, I could not, due to being unable to connect to the EA servers.  I tried a few of the usual tricks to get things to work, but to no avail.  I did manage to get to the loading screen and even hear audio at one point before being booted.

I tried for about 45 minutes to load a game.  I tried on my own a week later and actually managed to get into a game.  It seemed pretty enough, and ran smoothly, racked up a few kills, capped a couple of points before being kicked for... being unable to connect to EA servers.

I could try and raise this as a support issue, but anybody who has tried that with EA will know that you're not going to get anything useful.  There is something fundamentally incompatible with my computer and the game, and that's it.  So a refund for me.  But as a result, I cannot recommend you waste your money as you can land up with a lot of time down the drain with nothing to show for it.  Try battlebit instead.

The game has improved a lot since launch (particularly with the re-implementation of the class system) but there are a lot of problems with it that make it a little difficult to recommend without some caveats.
- The lack of a story would not have been much of an issue for BF1 or BFV, but in the case of BF2042, the setting can no longer provide the story in and of itself, as it is entirely made-up. This, in combination with the fact that it is character-focused, serve to render the setting rather shallow and un-immersive.
- The inclusion of "heroes" makes the game feel quite alien from other Battlefield titles. Having 5 clones of yourself running past you definitely does not help immersion. It also prevents people from expressing themselves using a style they enjoy, instead forcing them to use whatever styles are available for their particular specialist.
- The maps are pretty lifeless and lack cover in a lot of crucial ways. Map traversal and positioning relies too heavily on unique specialist abilities that "situational metas" often dominate. Going back to the setting, though I doubt this is actually the case, it almost feels like the "climate change has destroyed the world" backstory served more as an excuse for making maps that consisted of muddy hellscapes littered with a few assets than it did as a genuine plot point. The new map (Redacted) is polarizing but I find it to be a step in the right direction in terms of map variety.
- The movement system ("geometry traversal?") is extremely inconsistent and a big step down from BFV. You will often find your character failing to step over a 2-inch-tall rock without explicitly hitting the jump button. This makes movement in general quite difficult to rely on for positioning and leads to a lot of frustrating deaths.
- Voice chat is never used both because it literally does not work half of the time and because a lot of the players are on console. "All chat" is disabled by default, meaning that most people will not see your messages even if their text chat is visible in the first place. It is essentially impossible to coordinate anything without talking on a 3rd-party channel such as a Discord call.
- The party system can be buggy and often puts you in different squads, though I have not seen this happening nearly as much with the latest patch.
- Though the game doesn't feel over-monetized in the sense that it doesn't constantly push you towards microtransactions, the cosmetics that are available are generally pretty lame and also horrendously expensive, which really does not make them desirable in any way.
- The soundtrack sounds like it was made by a dollar store-variety Hans Zimmer. Calling it a soundtrack at all is a bit generous.

That being said, here are the reasons I am recommending the game anyway:
- There are virtually no cheaters, whether because they monitor reports or because the anticheat is much better. I've played for 200 hours and I've seen only 2 or 3 obvious cheaters.
- Though the specialist system certainly can lead to metas arising in certain situations, and some specialists are genuinely just not very good, I also find that people just play what they want to play, and it's actually pretty rare to see a large amount of people all playing a similar build.
- The addition of PvE modes is actually, in my opinion, a great one; there are certainly complaints to be made about the AI itself, but the fact that the game will never be completely unplayable, even when there is only one player online, is actually awesome.
- The gunplay is great and most of the weapons are pretty balanced. People complain a lot about various weapons from time to time but they are usually balanced over time.
- The specialist gadgets do lead to some very entertaining situations. I do wish that these were just generic subclasses rather than "heroes" though. I also like the idea of allowing any class to use any primary/secondary but giving bonuses to the "suggested" weapon types.

Overall, I would not buy this game for full price, but on a good sale it's worth it. Just remember that if you're a veteran Battlefield player, you might be disappointed with how much the game mechanics deviate from other installments.

Disclaimer: I was a pre-order day one player who refunded because of how broken and flawed the game was.

I bought it on sale for like 5 bucks, and that has to be one of the best purchases i've made for that price. The game's actually really fun now, and there's a pretty decent amount of content. They added the classes back!! Also leaderboards, more guns, maps, a ton of unlocks that you get by playing the game (not sure what's new though), and a lot of paid cosmetics in the store. 

I was worried about the battlepass, but it appears to be one of those that give you enough currency to get the next one. I think there's only a couple operators and weapons locked behind the elite upgrade ($$), but the base game is great by itself. There's kind of a lot here to do from infantry focused game modes to GOOD OL' battlefield all-out-war game modes. You can even find those 24/7 meat grinder servers on the "Portal" (custom lobbies with modifiers, some have bots, some have game modifiers). 


The operator skills are pretty fun and support a lot of different playstyles. One cool thing is that every 1st weekend of the month is 2x XP. It's for sure worth $30-$40 if you can grab it on sale. (There used to be a handful of sub $10 sales for 2042). Oh, also the maps range from fantastic to decent, with a couple of them being some of my favorite BF maps in recent memory.


Edit: I do kinda have an issue with weapon cosmetics. I'm not the biggest BF fan, I only played 3, 4, and 2042, but thoroughly loved each (2042 less, but still). So I know the camos usually try to stay realistic within reason, but dude 90% of the camos here are so bland and "safe". There's a lot of camos that just have a ton of build in "weathering" so its all scraped up and you don't get to really appreciate the full wrap. Over all, not a huge deal-breaker, but it's kinda annoying.

To me, it still feels like a Battlefield game, but I'm not sure how Battlefield vets feel about it because primary weapons are no longer locked to classes. You can run an LMG on any class now if you want. Recon is no longer entirely synonymous with sniper rifles. Each class gets some minor perks with those weapons, but none of the perks really completely outweigh not going with something else if you wanted to.

I also find it kind of weird that Assault kinda feels like BF4's Support and Support feels like BF4's Assault. I'd honestly like to see Ammo crates given to both Support and Assault to even out that weird feeling. I want to be the big dude with the big gun who gives out ammo again without feeling like I'm forced to be a field medic babysitter with the defib.

Also I really fucking hate the AI soldiers. To anyone who hasn't bought the game yet, if matches aren't full yet the game places AI bots in the match to make the game seem more populated. They're not hard to fight (they're actually super easy if you have any one-tap-headshot weapon) but they're like, omniscient to placed equipment and it gets annoying when I think I pull a massive flank on Redacted and die and then I watch some robot walk around the corner, magically sense all my equipment, and then shoot it all when, in comparison, I've seen real players who are leagues better than me be absolutely blind to my T-UGS and respawn beacon sitting literally inches away from them. Like no real players have gone out of their way to destroy my equipment until they've realized it was causing problems. But the AI bot players do it automatically if they have line of sight to any of it. It sucks.

Plus the AI soldiers give away my position to real players, whether I'm shooting them or they're shooting me, so I kill a bot thinking "alright cool" and then a real player suddenly has access to my red dot on the minimap, where as without that AI soldier it would've been a fair fight between me and him and I may have had the jump on him. It's not the same as shooting a real player. Like, if I'm 2v1 and I kill one guy I think "alright, cool, I got at least one of them in that fight.", but if I'm 2v1 and one of them is a bot, and I kill the bot first and die to the other guy, I can only think "Man, if only that bot wasn't there, I probably would've killed the real person." Which is kind of what I'm here to do in this [b] PLAYER* vs *PLAYER* [/b] first person shooter game.

I still like this game, but [u] please please please please please [/u] limit the effectiveness of AI soldiers. Nothing about them is 100% good. There needs to be a hard limit of like, a single squad of them per team. And they should be in their own squad. I don't want to see a squadmate down and go to save him only to realize I revived a bot instead of my other real non-squad teammates nearby.
They've done a lot for the game since the horrible launch. I would say it's definitely worth playing now, especially if you're a Battlefield fan.

As an avid fan of the Battlefield franchise, I approached Battlefield 2042 with high expectations, only to be met with an overwhelming sense of disappointment and frustration. DICE and Electronic Arts have managed to turn what was once a hallmark series for immersive and engaging multiplayer experiences into a prime example of how not to release a game.

The first and most glaring issue is the woeful state of the game at launch. Battlefield 2042 arrived riddled with bugs, glitches, and an astonishing lack of polish. The game's developers seemingly forgot that a smooth launch is crucial for player enjoyment. From constant crashes to game-breaking bugs, it felt like I was participating in a beta test rather than playing a finished product.

The lack of a traditional single-player campaign was a bold move, but the promised focus on a robust multiplayer experience failed to materialize. The much-touted "All-Out Warfare" mode felt more like "All-Out Chaos" due to the glaring imbalance in the game's design. Maps are sprawling but lack the intricate design that made previous Battlefield titles shine. The absence of a coherent narrative made the battles feel disconnected and meaningless, leaving players without a sense of purpose beyond mindless shooting.

Moreover, the introduction of specialists instead of traditional classes added an unnecessary layer of complexity and disrupted the delicate balance that previous games in the series had achieved. The removal of fan-favorite features like levolution and the absence of iconic Battlefield moments made the experience feel generic and uninspired.

The decision to rely heavily on a battle pass and microtransactions for in-game content is a blatant cash grab that further sours the gaming experience. The progression system feels tedious and unfulfilling, pushing players towards spending real money for cosmetic items that should have been included with the base game.

Lastly, the lack of meaningful post-launch support and the sluggish response to community feedback have left Battlefield 2042 feeling abandoned and unsupported. Promised updates and fixes have been slow to materialize, leaving players stuck with a broken and unfulfilling experience.

In conclusion, Battlefield 2042 stands as a testament to how mismanagement, a rushed release, and a disregard for the core elements that made the franchise great can lead to the downfall of a beloved gaming series. Save your money and avoid this disaster of a title at all costs.

This game isn't quite the same as my favorite Battlefield (Bad Company 2), but it feels like a lot of the things I loved about that game were re-purposed and expanded upon. Specifically there is a game mode called Breakthrough which is essentially DICE taking Rush and Conquest and combining them into a new, fun experience. 

I know this game has gotten a bad rep in the BF community at small and the mainstream gaming community at large because of its jacked state of launch, but it shows how much DICE has worked on bringing this game to a much more enjoyable, familiar state while being fresh and fun for those who have spent tens of hundreds of hours into games like BF3 and BadCo2.

One thing that does make me sad is that the Easy Anti-Cheat has basically made this game impossible to natively run on the Steam Deck (Windows is required to run the Anti-Cheat software), and EA does not seem like they are much interested in making their online games compatible with Proton/SteamOS. This game plays far better on M+K anyways, but the option would have been nice.

Overall, get this game on sale for like 10 bucks or less, or try it out through EA Play which is 5 bucks a month. It is a well made game and a lot of fun, but squads are kind of unstable and it's a bit ludicrous to pay 60 bucks for a game that has micro-transactions, season passes, and really only works on Windows computers and requires the EA launcher on top of it all. Ten years ago this practice was quasi-acceptable, but in 2023 F2P games have gotten a lot better to justify those kinds of business practices. Still a fun game and if you like Battlefield, you will like this game, but just don't fall for the full price tag imo.

After years of fixing, it's now a decent, but completely predictable, shooter. It has a few meta weapons that are competitive, but most guns are below average or horrible. TTK is ridiculous, so if you're average to above average with aiming, you'll need to use one of the small handful of meta weapons, which gets boring quickly. Oh, and 90% of the new maps are really awful. The entire game is a snoozer.

As an actual Battlefield game, it's astonishingly hot, utter garbage. No real, or believable, story. No teamwork required. Specialists are absolutely stupid with pathetic voice acting. The announcers for each team are a joke and super annoying -- especially the fake Russian accent. Many of the basics of BF like a real scoreboard, match-wide chat, etc. Simple things like having a basic crosshair sight, isn't possible. And, where in all previous Battlefields, most of the cosmetics are locked behind seasons.

I'd bet this is the end of the franchise for me as I expect them to churn out another game that attempts to be CoD. I hope I'm wrong, but knowing EA, this game marked the end of what made Battlefield so special.

When you win, it's not fun running over them, when you lose, there was absolutely nothing you could do to win.
Honestly, this game has gotten a lot better since launch. it still has a small bit of cod in it but it feels like a BF game now and i highly recommend it.

I got this game on sale for about $12 CAD, and its very worth it. First off, no, it is not the EXACT same as previous entries in the series (I've played BF3, BF4, and BF1), however it has the same charm as those games.

I haven't experienced many bugs, at least not major ones. The "specialists" don't feel like heroes from Apex Legends or anything like that, they feel as though they fit into certain roles. Those roles are not the EXACT same as previous games, but its clear that everyone still has a job to fulfil on the team.

I do definitely recommend the game now, but not for full price (although I wouldn't recommend any game with the high price most AAA games have nowadays, regardless of how good it is).

Would I say this game is worth $60 now probably not but for what there is and how far it's come, I would recommend .

Battlefield 2042 : By Triple F

DICE has once again shattered the boundaries of the first-person shooter genre with their latest masterpiece, "Battlefield 2042." As the gaming world eagerly awaited its release, the game proved itself to be a breathtaking leap into the future, redefining both the scale of battle and the limits of innovation.

Set in a near-future world scarred by climate crisis and geopolitical upheaval, "Battlefield 2042" presents a grim yet captivating backdrop for its intense battles. The attention to detail in the game's environments is awe-inspiring, showcasing the devastating consequences of unchecked climate change while seamlessly integrating them into the game-play dynamics. From flooded cityscapes to desolate desert landscapes, each map is a masterpiece in itself, setting the stage for epic warfare that spans continents.

What truly sets "Battlefield 2042" apart is the revolutionary "All-Out Warfare" game mode. With up to 128 players engaging in battles of unprecedented scale, the chaos unfolds on an unparalleled level. The sheer scope of the battles is jaw-dropping; watching fighter jets scream overhead, tanks rumble through urban warzones, and infantry engage in close-quarters combat creates an immersion that was previously unimaginable. The game's cutting-edge technology ensures that the battles are not only massive but also incredibly detailed, with destruction rendering environments dynamically as bullets fly and explosives detonate.

The hallmark of the Battlefield series – destruction – reaches new heights in 2042. Virtually every structure in the game is destructible, from skyscrapers to shacks. This elevates strategy to a whole new level; there's nothing quite like collapsing a building on enemy forces or blasting open new routes through the map with a well-placed rocket.

"Battlefield 2042" introduces the "Specialist" system, a departure from traditional classes. This change injects a fresh dynamic into game-play by allowing players to customize their load-outs with a primary weapon, secondary weapon, gadget, and unique trait. The result is a remarkable degree of personalization, encouraging players to experiment and adapt their play-styles. It's a move that's sure to be divisive among veterans, but one that undeniably adds depth and innovation to the experience.

Visually, "Battlefield 2042" is a stunning achievement. The level of detail, from character models to weather effects, is a testament to the developers' commitment to pushing the boundaries of graphical fidelity. Combined with a dynamic weather system that can turn the tide of battle in an instant, the game maintains an immersive realism that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

However, no game is without its flaws. "Battlefield 2042's" launch was not without technical hiccups, which slightly marred the initial experience. Server issues and occasional bugs did lead to frustration, but DICE's commitment to rapid fixes and updates demonstrated their dedication to delivering a polished product.

In the end, "Battlefield 2042" is a triumphant celebration of chaos, innovation, and the sheer scale of modern warfare. With its breathtaking visuals, groundbreaking game-play mechanics, and expansive battles, the game propels the first-person shooter genre into a new era. DICE has once again proven themselves as pioneers in the industry, redefining what players can expect from a multiplayer shooter. "Battlefield 2042" isn't just a game; it's an experience that will be remembered for years to come.

Has come a long way since launch, and I wholeheartedly recommend the game in its current state.

Devs have listened to community feedback, changing the class system to a more classic-Battlefield system, reworked entire maps that were disliked, and added in tons of new and old school weapons.

The time to kill feels just right. Almost every weapon feels good to use, so there's no "meta". Some will swear by a few ARs or SMGs, but theres always another weapon in the same class that can perform just as well. Movement is fast and sleek, coupled with sprint-slide-bunny hop even advanced movement enjoyers will find something to work with. 

Outside of the standard 64 or 128 player Conquest modes, there are a plethora of rotating modes weekly you can play to shake things up. Vehicle Supremacy, Air Supremacy, TDM, 8v8, modes like Battlefield Bad Company 2 conquest, etc. 

Highly recommend picking this up if you're looking for a hectic fast paced shooter.

*EDIT Dec 26th 2023 : So after 2 years worth of updates and fixes, I'd say this game is...okay. The gunplay is classic battlefield so pretty good, they finally added in squads and scoreboards and stuff, and most importantly we got the classic class based system back (or at least a modified version of it).

If you can get this game at a discount, I'd say it's definitely worth a shot. There's enough players nowadays that you won't have to worry about empty servers, and there's a decent amount content to play with. 

However I think the map design is still pretty flawed. Compared to past Battlefields, the maps were artificially enlarged to support 128 players, however because of that there is a lot of big open areas with no cover whatsoever, and you get shot to death pretty easily (it could also just be a skill issue). 

On top of that the battle pass system is...well there's not much I can say about this. Personally I prefer the old Premium Pass system but in today's climate I think battle passes are inevitable, but at least I don't feel as pressured into paying for microtransactions as compared to other games I guess.

Overall it's a decent game with still some fundamental flaws, but at a discount it's definitely worth a pickup.

Below is the original review : 

I don't know what else to say man, I knew it was coming, but this game is probably the biggest disappointment of this year.

Even excluding all the game play changes like the operator system and whatnot, the performance issues are just way too severe. And the thing is, you won't realize it since every reviewer tends to use ultra high ends CPU's to test the game, but the problem is that this game is SEVERELY CPU bottlenecked. Even when everything turned to ULTRA at 3440x1440, my 3080 was only getting 40~50% usage, and my i5 8500 was constantly pegged at 98~100%.

When other battle royale games also have 100 players yet this one runs like absolute crap, you know you fucked up.
And I mean the graphics look nice, but they're not ULTRA REALISTIC or anything. There are other games that have come out this year that manage to run better yet look better.

Putting performance aside, the UI is....atrocious. Who designed the main screen ? Not only is it incredibly low res, doens't stretch out to ultrawide displays, the icons are WAY too big. Same goes for the menu options. Everything is either too blown up or color coded in a way that's hard to notice. This is a joke.

I had my fun in Battlefield portal, but this is a new game, I WANT to play the new mode. Hazard zone so far has been incredibly boring and barrren. All out warfare runs like absolute crap and everyone just gathers around the objectives, which kinda makes the big maps pointless. 

Overall, I wouldn't recommend getting this game at its current state. This shouldn't either been delayed for another year or two, or they shouldn't just cut off hazard zone and focused on the other two modes. What an absolute disgrace this game is.

Introduction:
My return to Battlefield 2042 has been met with persistent challenges, as the game struggles to deliver the immersive experience expected from the renowned franchise. Despite the promise of a futuristic setting in 2042, my gameplay has been hindered by a series of issues. Let's delve into the highs and lows of this latest installment.

Graphics and Character Design:
Battlefield 2042 impresses with its heightened graphics and character design. The futuristic setting is visually stunning, with character customization offering a welcomed layer of aesthetic appeal.

Cons:

Map Size and Detail:
The allure of the future is overshadowed by the game's cramped maps, sacrificing diversity for excessive detail. Battlefield 2042's maps feel restrictive, hindering the potential for immersive and expansive gameplay.

Graphics vs. Gameplay:
Despite the visual enhancements, Battlefield 2042 falls into the trap of prioritizing aesthetics over dynamic gameplay. The game struggles to strike a balance, leaving players longing for a more engaging and interactive gaming environment.

Lack of Communication:
Communication breakdowns persist in Battlefield 2042, a stark departure from the series' history. Drawing parallels to Squad's successful communication-centric approach, the absence of effective in-game communication diminishes the overall Battlefield experience.

Player Durability and Class System:
High player durability and an unrestricted class system contribute to frustratingly prolonged firefights and gameplay imbalances. Battlefield 2042 needs to reassess these elements to restore the strategic depth that defines the franchise.

Casual Gameplay:
The game leans into a casual gameplay mindset, neglecting the crucial balance between competition and realism. A faster pace shouldn't sacrifice strategic depth, and Battlefield 2042 could learn from successful titles like Fortnite in finding this equilibrium.

Gameplay Pace:
Battlefield 2042's relentless combat pace leaves little room for quiet moments, creating an exhausting experience. Striking a balance akin to PUBG or Siege would alleviate the intensity and improve overall gameplay satisfaction.

Pros:
Amidst the challenges, Battlefield 2042 shines in its improved graphics and character design, providing players with a visually appealing futuristic battlefield.

Campaign Mode:
One glaring omission is the absence of a campaign mode, a feature that has historically added depth and connection to the Battlefield experience. Reintroducing a well-crafted campaign could bridge the gap between single-player and multiplayer, enhancing overall immersion.

Conclusion:
Battlefield 2042, while visually impressive, grapples with fundamental issues that compromise the overall gaming experience. Addressing map design, communication features, and gameplay balance is essential for the game to reclaim its status as a premier multiplayer title in the Battlefield series.

Update 12/05/23: So 2 years later and here's what I have to say.

This is NOT a *Battlefield* game like that we all once knew and loved. Do not buy this with the intention of jumping reliving *Battlefield* from 2013 or earlier. This is a new era of *Battlefield* built for this generation of players. Progression is easy, matches are fast, and team play is even worse. Think *Fortnite* tried to make a *Battlefield* game and you end up here. The list of negatives for the game is long, even longer if you try to compare it to past games of the franchise so do you research before you but or better... Just click away now and don't.

All that said, I have been playing the game again because I'm one of the unlucky suckers that Pre-Ordered the game back when EA still had somewhat of a reputation. I still don't feel like I've gotten my moneys worth of enjoyment out of this, and likely won't ever. Game is ok in short bursts (speaking from a Veteran of the franchises POV), but even better if you play the "Portal". Think Halo 4 custom games but for *Battlefield*. 

At the end of the day, If you still really want to buy this and can look past the *Battlefield* name as it was. Don't spend more than $25.
This is the best Battlefield I've played ever since Battelfield Bad Company 2. AWESOME physics, fun, game modes, just awesome!

From the instabilities at launch, the 8mo it took just to get something simple that should have already existed (scoreboard), to the poor map design, the mutilation of classes and that classic battlefield 'feel'. 
The gas lighting of the players, the greed driven micro-transactions, (not so micro anyways).
From the subtle ad's slipped into the game (oh hi Logitech), lack of 128v128 game modes, this whole thing has been an embarrassment of a game from day one. 

Can still get those rare 'only in BF' moments, worth running around and giving it a go every now and again, but can't recommend anybody pays more than $9.99 for this hot mess.

1yr later: Still not there yet, playing with friends is an atrocious mess, unable to remain in the same match at times, put into different squads at other times, this game is so anti-team play it's really just appalling. No way to report players suspected of cheating; just little things that seem so basic to a FPS.

2yrs later: aight for 9$ I'd say it's finally well priced.

Summary:
Though the gameplay is solid, with gunplay and movement being highlights, it falls short due to engine issues and strange design choices. I wouldn't recommend this to new players and only suggest this to true battlefield fanatics.

Bullet point review:

- This game is a real mixed bag

- Good enough fundamental game-play (retroactive implementation of the class system works, however you can feel the seams)

- There is no such thing as having "a quick game" (the loading times are long and plenty)

- Poor balancing (Air vehicles are consistently too powerful, some operators are useless - most a viable. Team balancing is often fair, sometimes god awful)

- No map filters or search! (Most maps are okay, a few good, a few bad with it often depending on the game-mode. The lack of filtering only highlights the bad maps even more, made worse by the loading times)

- Love the gun play and movement! (though the long engagement ranges are frustrating sometimes seeing as many of the maps have long sight lines)

Overall: 
6/10

I'm indifferent to 2042. Good gameplay (most of the time) but y'all really dropped the ball.

First: The bug with the Armor Hunter for one of the specialists. From what I have read, this is a long-standing issue in which at random, when you use the armor hunter, you're gonna find that your vehicle camera is now in the middle and below the map for some reason. Even changing sessions and all won't work, you have to restart the game which is ridiculous.

Second: BF2042 has an interesting theme to it. It's good, I like that some of the previous characters were brought in (like Irish from 4) but where the hell is the story? No campaign, no "hey this is what happened", just all multiplayer. Which, sure, is fine but then what's the point of having a story to each of the specialists and all these loading quotes? What the hell happened to Hannah? WTF is a No-Pat?!

Third: AI multiplayer matches. This I like, only because it seems to be hard to actually find a match in the late evening/early morning. However, it's a little odd that even if I play on the beginner difficulty in an AI conquest match, I get that same XP as if it was a regular PvP match. Why is this a thing? It's as if instead of grinding for things (as normal multiplayer games go), you're just cheating through by letting people get what they want. In a way.

Fourth: what the hell is this spawn shit outside of the team zone? If you have control over D1 or D2 for example, why do I end up spawning 4 feet away from an enemy tank that's about to run me over?

Fifth: Honestly I should of put this one first but whoever designed the anti-cheat needs a kick in the shin. It's horrible, it's buggy, and it's unstable to all hell. Downloaded the game and it took me 5 hours to figure out why EA AntiCheat is going off and won't let me start the game. Never have cheated in an online match, never paid for any of that crap, but yet God forbid I have Driver Signature enforcement off (previous project I messed with in development, once again not a cheat). Not only that, but the random moments where I have nothing running in the background, all of a sudden the game has to shut down "because Anticheat has detected a forbidden process to be running". What process? The damn OS?

I'd say I would like to see some changes but for the 8$ or whatever I got for this game, it's really only worth that much. It's clear that even with that armor hunter glitch being still active after a year, there is no concern for this game and it's stability.

I've tolerated the many issues this game has had and continues to have just to try to capture the nostalgia & enjoyment that DICE products provided in the past with my friends. 

Despite the abysmal launch, horrible changes to the game mechanics that they eventually rolled back on when everyone wanted a refund etc. Not to mention that myself and all my friends with high end gaming PC's practically overheated and wrecked our PC's to play this flaming pile of hot garbage.

Its a shame when indie studios with less resources and staff can do circles around Triple A major studios who drag the lifeless half finished, buggy corpse of a franchise to milk it for every penny. 

Its no wonder tons of players have abandoned this shell of a game to support games like BattleBit Remastered. 

RIP Dice you were gods among your peers once upon a time.

PS:
This is still better than Call of Duty.

The game if fairly fun even though it isn't quite perfect and could be great yet it suffers from a lot of issues.


+ PROS +
++++++++
+ Huge Maps
+ Decent Gameplay
+ Decent Audio
+ Longer Multiplayer Matches
+ Multiplayer/Co-OP
+ Can play matches Solo and with AI 
+ On-the-Fly Weapon Customization
+ Weapon and Vehicle Call-Ins on the Fly
+ New 4-player Survival-like Mode
+ Very Challenging Gameplay due to larger maps and more players


- CONS -
-----------
- No idea why the heck they left out a Campaign, it's a huge heart of the BF Game Series and should not have been ignored nor left out at all which was a huge mistake by the devs in almost every way
- Not that many weapons actually
- Not that much customization and needs improved a heck of a lot
- Removed Arsenal Call-Ins Etc such as missles, smoke to bombard areas which was not a smart move at all
- Throwing Grenades etc is just strange and annoying, not sure why devs changed it, bad idea
- Weird random little glitches namely with vehicles
- Rubber-banding meshes and textures that shake
- Not many vehicles per player count, unacceptable, parked vehicles on map should also be drivable
- Still can't slide very well at all yet, another thing that is unacceptable at this point for a game of this style
- Wingsuit isn't on all classes, you have to be Sundance to use it which is misleading since not everyone can use it which just sucks because if all classes had it that would be a lot more interesting and fun
- No Operations or Frontlines Modes which is rather disappointing
- Can be hard to get Kills due to larger maps with more players
- Horrible Lag and performance issues galore, seems to be a problem with each season so far
- I miss the Fortification System from Battlefield V, they should have kept that
- I miss the death animation from Battlefield V, it was a nice touch, calling out while bleeding out
- The game itself is very poorly optimized in nearly every possible way to the point that you pretty much need a jet engine just to run it even if you already have rtx. (I found that having a lot more than 16gb ram helps a ton and appears to be a big cause - bf2042 is extremely heavy on your system ram usage)
- EA/Dice made a really dumb decision to axe the new (2023) Battlefield Mobile that could have been great
- Extremely Rude Teammates and Squadmates that will leave you for dead quite often
- Black Screen constantly after ending a match now all of a sudden since Season 4.


= VERDICT = 
===========
While I do love the game there are a number of obvious issues that plague the game each release and each season sadly although it's certainly often playable. I've been a long time battlefield player and to me it feels more like a war with fully destructable environments unlike other shooter games which no other game has yet to match or create something of the sort better, a few have tried and failed in comparison. However the game in its current state as of Season 2 and now again with Season 3 has become unplayable so I cannot recommend it.

Spent thousands of hours in BC2, BF3, BF4, Hardline, and BF1 - this has gone dramatically further down the slope of bad decisions that started with BFV. Somehow the engine feels worse than ever especially with dead environments and muffled sound. There are a handful of decent servers running community based settings but other than that it's just an arcade bot shooter. If there are more concurrent players in a game that's a decade old or more, maybe it's time to go back to your roots.

I finally bought this game 2 years after release on sale for 10€. Having last played during the "beta" shortly before release, certainly a lot has improved and changed for the better.
Now, BF2042 is finally what most people expected - a more or less typical Battlefield game. But that's it - if you have played any Battlefield since BF3 from 2011, you know exactly what you are going to get here. If you are happy with this, then BF2042 is a decent game to play. If you expect any meaningful advancement to the typical Battlefield experience you will be disappointed. "Bland" is the best word to describe this game.
